questions.text: What is the name of the first neuron in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bipolar cells:

  • Bipolar cells are the first-order neurons. These cells receive signals from photoreceptor cells and transmit them to ganglion cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ganglion cells: Ganglion cells are the second-order neurons. They receive signals from bipolar cells and transmit these signals along their axons, forming the optic nerve to the lateral geniculate body.

Option C - Cells in lateral geniculate body: Lateral Geniculate body is the third-order neuron. The optic nerve fibers synapse at the LGN in the thalamus.

Option D - Rods and Cones: These cells are photoreceptors and they are end receptors. They detect light and convert it into electrical signals.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not exemplify a feed-forward control mechanism?

choices.text: Exercise resulting in heart rate increase

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Exercise resulting in heart rate increase:

  • Exercise-induced heart rate increase, illustrates feedback, not feedforward control. The heart rate elevates in response to immediate exercise demands, rather than anticipatorily preparing for changes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Temperature regulation: This is an example of a feedforward control mechanism. For instance, when the body anticipates exposure to cold temperatures, it may initiate processes like vasoconstriction and shivering to maintain or raise body temperature before it actually drops significantly.

Option B - Cephalic phase of gastric secretion: The cephalic phase of gastric secretion is indeed a feedforward control mechanism. It occurs before food reaches the stomach, and sensory stimuli such as the sight and smell of food can trigger the release of gastric juices in anticipation of digestion.

Option C - Cerebellar action in motor coordination: The cerebellum plays a significant role in motor coordination and is involved in feedforward control. It helps anticipate and make adjustments to muscle activities to coordinate movements effectively.

questions.text: I-125 labeled albumin is used for measurement of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Plasma volume:

  • I-125 labeled albumin is commonly used to measure plasma volume. I-125 is a iodine labeled albumin that is injected into the bloodstream.
  • It is impermeable to capillaries and does not dissociate into interstitial fluid and intracellular fluid. So, by measuring the dilution of the labeled albumin in the plasma, the total volume of plasma can be determined.
  • Evan’s blue is another substance that can be used for determining plasma volume.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. I-125 labeled iodine is used to measure the plasma volume.

questions.text: For its action, which hormone is able to cross the plasma membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Thyroxine:

Thyroxine (T4) is a thyroid hormone that crosses the plasma membrane to exert its action. Once inside the target cells, thyroxine is converted to its active form, triiodothyronine (T3), which then binds to nuclear receptors and affects gene transcription, thus influencing various metabolic processes.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Epinephrine: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a hormone that acts on cell surface receptors. It binds to specific receptors on the cell surface, triggering a cascade of intracellular signaling events to initiate its physiological effects. It does not cross the plasma membrane.

Option C - Glucagon: Glucagon is a hormone that acts on cell surface receptors. It binds to specific receptors on target cells, primarily in the liver, promoting glycogen breakdown and the release of glucose into the bloodstream. Glucagon does not cross the plasma membrane.

Option D - Insulin: Insulin is a hormone that acts on cell surface receptors. It binds to specific receptors on target cells, such as muscle and adipose tissue, promoting glucose uptake and regulating glucose metabolism. Insulin does not cross the plasma membrane.

questions.text: What would be the resulting lung volume if the chest wall is excluded and the lung is allowed to undergo elastic recoil?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A.

  • Minimum volume: The minimum volume of the lung refers to the volume of the lung when it is allowed to undergo maximum elastic recoil without any opposing forces from the chest wall. It is the smallest volume the lung can reach during expiration.

Incorrect options 

Option B. Zero: If the lung undergoes elastic recoil without the chest wall, it does not mean that the lung volume would reach zero. The lungs still have residual air and do not collapse completely.

Option C. Functional residual capacity (FRC): FRC is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration, when the forces of lung recoil and chest wall expansion are in equilibrium. It is the volume at which the lung and chest wall exert equal but opposite forces.

Option D. Residual volume: The residual volume is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a maximal expiration. It represents the air that cannot be expelled from the lungs and serves to keep the alveoli open.

questions.text: What is the cause of "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Downregulation of aquaporin 2 production:

  • In SIADH, excessive ADH secretion causes water retention. Initially, ADH upregulates aquaporin 2 channels, increasing water reabsorption. Over time, aquaporin 2 production decreases, leading to "vasopressin escape" and allowing water excretion despite continued ADH release.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: When calculating the quantity of IV fluids required for a patient, what amount of daily transient loss/insensible loss would you consider?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 500-600 ml:

  • Constant water evaporation occurs in our body during respiration or directly from the skin's surface, which is normal, is referred to as insensible water loss.
  • Normally, 700 ml of water evaporates from our body daily. 350 ml of water is evaporated from the skin's surface and 350 ml from the respiratory tract.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below causes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Contralateral hemiplegia:

 

  •  The highlighted area is the medullary pyramids, situated in the medulla oblongata of the brainstem. Lesions here result in contralateral hemiplegia, where damage affects motor fibers crossing over to the opposite side of the body. These fibers form the corticospinal tracts, transmitting motor signals from the brain to the spinal cord and muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option B -  Ataxia refers to a lack of coordination of voluntary muscle movements. Lesions in other areas of the brain, such as the cerebellum, are more commonly associated with ataxia.

Option C - Tinnitus, the perception of ringing or noise in the ears, is usually linked to auditory system problems like inner ear or auditory nerve damage, not lesions in the medullary pyramids.

Option D - Facial palsy is usually due to lesions in the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) from the pons, not the medullary pyramids.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image given below:-
questions.solution:
Option B-Ulnar Artery:

  • The structure marked in the image is the ulnar artery. The ulnar artery is one of the main arteries in the forearm and hand. It runs along the ulnar side (medial side) of the forearm and supplies blood to the muscles and tissues of the forearm and hand.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. The structure marked in the image isn't the ulnar nerve, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the hand and forearm as a separate anatomical entity.

Option C. The structure in the image isn't the superficial radial artery, which is situated on the radial (lateral) side of the forearm, nearer to the skin surface.

Option D. The structure in the image isn't the median nerve, a major nerve in the arm that provides motor and sensory innervation to the hand and forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the lesion of the structure indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D.

  •  The lesion marked by the arrow leads to wrist drop. Wrist drop refers to a condition where the wrist is unable to maintain an extended position and hangs in a flexed position. It occurs due to weakness or paralysis of the muscles that extend the wrist, particularly the extensor muscles in the posterior compartment of the forearm. The most common cause of wrist drop is damage or compression of the radial nerve, which innervates these muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Ape thumb deformity is when the thumb aligns more with the fingers, resembling an ape's thumb. It often occurs due to median nerve injuries..

Option B. Claw hand is a deformity marked by hyperextended metacarpophalangeal joints and flexed interphalangeal joints, giving the hand a claw-like look. It's commonly linked to ulnar nerve injuries.

Option C. Claudication is muscle pain due to poor blood flow during exercise, often in lower limbs, linked to peripheral artery disease.

questions.text: All of the following form the marked structure except:
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option D.

  • This is the correct answer. The 2nd palmar interossei muscle does not form the marked structure. The palmar interossei muscles are located in the palm of the hand and are responsible for adduction of the fingers toward the midline of the hand. They do not directly contribute to the formation of the dorsal digital expansion on the dorsal side of the fingers.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. The 2nd dorsal interossei muscle is involved in forming the marked structure. The dorsal digital expansion is formed by the dorsal interossei muscles, which are located between the metacarpal bones of the hand. They extend from the metacarpal bones to the extensor expansions on the dorsal side of the fingers.

Option B. The lumbricals extensor digitorum muscles are involved in forming the marked structure. The lumbrical muscles arise from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus and pass through the dorsal digital expansion. They contribute to the extension of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints.

Option C. The extensor digitorum muscle is involved in forming the marked structure. The extensor digitorum muscle is located on the dorsal side of the forearm and gives rise to the tendons that insert into the dorsal digital expansions. It is responsible for the extension of the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints, proximal interphalangeal joints, and distal interphalangeal joints.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent structures of the brachial plexus does not provide any branches?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D.

  • Divisions: Division does not give branches in the Brachial Plexus.
  • However, the Root, cords, trunks in the brachial plexus do give branches.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B & C:Root, Cord and Tunks give branches

questions.text: Identify the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A.

  • Stomach: The correct option is option A. The stomach is located in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen, near the left kidney. It is anatomically adjacent to the left kidney.

Incorrect options: 

Option B. Spleen: The spleen is an incorrect option. While the spleen is also located in the upper left quadrant of the abdomen, it is positioned more laterally and superiorly compared to the left kidney.

Option C. 2nd part of duodenum: The second part of the duodenum is an incorrect option. The duodenum is a part of the small intestine, and it is located in the central and upper abdomen. It is positioned more medially and inferiorly compared to the left kidney.

Option D. Pancreas: Option D is not explained in the initial question. However, the pancreas is an incorrect option in relation to the marked area. The pancreas is located behind the stomach and extends horizontally across the abdomen.

questions.text: The blood supply to the structure marked in the image is by:
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Anterior cerebral artery:

  • The anterior cerebral artery is one of the main arteries that supply blood to the brain. It arises from the internal carotid artery and provides blood supply to the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemispheres. It also supplies blood to the fornix, which is part of the limbic system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vertebral artery: The vertebral arteries, from the subclavian arteries, ascend through vertebrae to nourish the back of the brain, but they don't directly supply the fornix.

Option B - Internal carotid artery: The internal carotid arteries are major arteries that supply blood to the anterior part of the brain, but they do not directly supply the fornix.

Option D - Middle cerebral artery: The middle cerebral artery, a major branch of the internal carotid artery, feeds blood to the lateral parts of the cerebral hemispheres but doesn't directly nourish the fornix.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trochlear nerve:

  • The structure marked in the image is the Superior oblique muscle and it is supplied by the trochlear nerve.
  • The trochlear nerve is the fourth cranial nerve and is responsible for innervating the superior oblique muscle of the eye.
  • It is unique in its course and innervation compared to the other ocular motor nerves.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - The oculomotor nerve doesn't innervate the structure in the image. It controls eye movement muscles such as the superior rectus, inferior rectus, medial rectus, and inferior oblique muscles.

Option C - The trigeminal nerve does not supply the structure marked in the image. The trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the face, including the skin, mucous membranes, and teeth, and controls the muscles of mastication.

Option D - The abducens nerve does not supply the structure marked in the image. The abducens nerve, the sixth cranial nerve, innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, controlling outward eye movement.the trochlear nerve.

questions.text: During surgery, the patient experienced aspiration without any alteration in their voice. Which nerve is most likely to have been damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for innervating the muscles of the pharynx, including the stylopharyngeus muscle. Lesioning of the glossopharyngeal nerve can lead to impaired swallowing function, which can manifest as aspiration without voice change.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aspiration without voice change suggests a specific lesion unrelated to the vagus nerve, despite its involvement in innervating laryngeal and pharyngeal muscles.

Option B - A lesion of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve, can result in voice changes like hoarseness. However, it's less likely to cause aspiration without voice change.

Option C - A lesion of the superior laryngeal nerve, part of the vagus nerve, may alter voice quality by impacting the cricothyroid muscle. However, it typically isn't associated with aspiration without voice changes.

questions.text:
In the given section of the heart, match the marked (A,B,C&D) structures.




	Musculi pectinate 
	Anterior papillary muscle of left ventricle 
	Anterior papillary muscle of right ventricle 
	Anterior leaflet of mitral valve 
	membranous part of ventricular septum
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A-5, B-3, C-2, D-1:

A - Membranous part of ventricular septum

B - Anterior papillary muscle of right ventricle

C - Anterior papillary muscle of left ventricle

D - Musculi pectinate


Incorrect Options - A, B & D are incorrect answer

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used classify—
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A.

  • Acute kidney injury This option is correct. AKIN (Acute Kidney Injury Network) and RIFLE (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage kidney disease) criteria are used to classify and diagnose acute kidney injury. These criteria consider changes in serum creatinine levels, urine output, and the time frame in which these changes occur to determine the severity of acute kidney injury.

Incorrect options:

Option B. Chronic renal failure This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify chronic renal failure. Chronic renal failure is a progressive, long-term condition characterized by a permanent loss of kidney function over time. It is usually diagnosed and classified based on the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) and the presence of kidney damage lasting for at least three months.

Option C. Acute glomerulonephritis This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify acute glomerulonephritis. Acute glomerulonephritis refers to the inflammation and damage of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It is typically diagnosed through clinical symptoms, laboratory tests, and kidney biopsies.

Option D. Nephrotic syndrome This option is incorrect. AKIN and RIFLE criteria are not used to classify nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome is a collection of symptoms characterized by increased proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia. It is usually diagnosed based on clinical findings, urine tests, and blood tests.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the key clinical features used to diagnose Lewy body dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Orthostatic hypotension:

  • This option is correct. Orthostatic hypotension, which refers to a drop in blood pressure upon standing, is not a core clinical feature of LBD. While some individuals with LBD may experience orthostatic hypotension, it is not specific to the diagnosis and can be seen in other neurological or cardiovascular conditions as well.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fluctuating cognition: This is a core clinical feature of Lewy body dementia (LBD). Patients with LBD commonly experience variations in cognitive function, such as fluctuations in attention, alertness, and ability to process information.

Option B - Recurrent visual hallucinations: This is a core clinical feature of LBD. Visual hallucinations, often vivid and detailed, are a common symptom in LBD.

Option C - REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD): This is a core clinical feature of LBD and considered prodromal symptom. RBD refers to a disturbance during REM sleep where individuals physically act out their dreams, sometimes leading to injury or harm to themselves or their bed partners.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient experiencing repeated inflammation of the optic nerve in both eyes along with widespread inflammation of the spinal cord, and exhibiting visual acuity of 6/60 in the right eye and 6/18 in the left eye, with only a partial response to steroid treatment?

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Neuromyelitis optica:

  • NMO is a rare autoimmune disorder, also known as Devic’s disease, characterized by bilateral optic neuritis and rapidly progresses to blindness.
  • Other clinical characteristics include Area postrema syndrome, Brainstem syndrome, Cerebral syndrome, Diencephalic syndrome, Narcolepsy, and longitudinal extensive transverse myelitis

 

Incorrect options: 

Option B - Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord: This option is incorrect. Subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord is typically associated with vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to neurological symptoms such as sensory disturbances, difficulty walking, and spasticity. Option C - Posterior cerebral artery stroke: This option is incorrect. Posterior cerebral artery stroke refers to an ischemic stroke affecting the posterior cerebral artery territory of the brain.

Option D - Neurosyphilis: This option is incorrect. Neurosyphilis can present with various neurological symptoms, but recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis are not typical features of neurosyphilis.

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - High glucose:

  • High glucose levels are typically not a characteristic feature of pleural effusion in rheumatoid arthritis. Elevated glucose levels in pleural fluid are commonly associated with conditions such as bacterial infections or malignancies. Rheumatoid effusion is usually associated with glucose <40 mg/dL.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - RA factor: RA factor (rheumatoid factor) is an autoantibody commonly found in the blood of individuals with rheumatoid arthritis. It can also be detected in the pleural effusion fluid of RA patients.

Option C - Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals can be present in the pleural effusion fluid of rheumatoid arthritis patients. These crystals may form due to inflammation and the breakdown of cellular membranes.

Option D - High LDH: High LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) levels are commonly seen in pleural effusions, including those associated with rheumatoid arthritis. LDH is an enzyme released from damaged or inflamed cells, and its elevation in the pleural fluid can indicate inflammation or tissue damage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old was brought ro OPD with rapidly progressing dementia and myoclonus. Below is the EEG of the patient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Creuzfeldt-Jakob disease:

  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a rare degenerative neurological disorder. The EEG pattern in CJD often shows characteristic findings, including periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) and generalized slowing, which are consistent with the given EEG pattern.
  • Periodic sharp wave complexes are high voltage burst every few seconds, going upward only.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The EEG pattern in hepatic encephalopathy typically shows diffuse slowing rather than the specific pattern seen in the given EEG.

Option C - Generalized tonic-clonic seizures (also known as grand mal seizures) typically manifest with a EEG pattern characterized by generalized spike and wave discharges during the seizure activity.

Option D - The EEG findings in herpes simplex encephalitis may show focal or multifocal abnormalities, such as periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs) or focal slowing, which are different from the EEG pattern observed in the given image.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in managing a patient with the following ECG, who has already undergone carotid massage and received IV adenosine, but currently has a blood pressure reading of 60/30 mm Hg upon presentation to the emergency room?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C.

  •  Synchronized cardioversion: Synchronized cardioversion is the next best step of management in this scenario. It involves delivering a synchronized electrical shock to the heart at a specific moment in the cardiac cycle to restore normal sinus rhythm. It is an effective method for terminating PSVT and can rapidly improve the patient's condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Repeat inj adenosine 6 mg: Adenosine is a medication used to treat supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). However, since the patient has already received adenosine and it did not result in the termination of the arrhythmia, repeating the same dose is unlikely to be effective.

Option B. Inj amiodarone 300 mg: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic medication that can be used for various types of arrhythmias. However, in this case, the patient's blood pressure is already low, and amiodarone may further lower the blood pressure, potentially causing hemodynamic instability.

Option D. DC cardioversion: DC cardioversion, also known as defibrillation, is not appropriate for this patient as it is used to treat life-threatening arrhythmias such as ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia. In PSVT, which is a regular but rapid rhythm, synchronized cardioversion is the preferred approach.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Haemorrhagic mediastinitis:

  • This is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax. It is characterized by severe chest pain, shortness of breath, and mediastinal widening on imaging. Hemorrhagic mediastinitis refers to the presence of bleeding and inflammation in the mediastinum, the area between the lungs.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atypical pneumonia: This is not the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax. While respiratory symptoms can occur, they are not typically indicative of a typical pneumonia.

Option C - Lung abscess: Although lung abscess can occur in some cases of inhalational anthrax, it is not the most common presentation. Lung abscesses are localized collections of pus within the lung parenchyma.

Option D - Broncho-pulmonary pneumonia: While pneumonia can occur in inhalational anthrax, it typically presents as a severe form with features of haemorrhagic mediastinitis rather than a typical broncho-pulmonary pneumonia.

questions.text: In the ICU, a patient experiencing renal failure presents with vomiting. Analysis of arterial blood gases reveals a pH level of 7.4, sodium (Na+) concentration of 140 mEq/L, chloride (CI-) concentration of 100 mEq/L, bicarbonate (HCO3-) concentration of 24 mEq/L, and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) of 40 mmHg. What metabolic abnormality is most likely occurring?

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C.

  •  High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis. The low sodium level suggests hyponatremia, which is associated with metabolic alkalosis. The elevated anion gap indicates the presence of a metabolic acidosis, likely due to renal failure or other underlying causes
    • Let's analyze the given ABG values:
    • pH: 7.4 (within the normal range, indicating no primary acid-base disturbance)
    • Na+: 140 mEq/L (low)
    • Cl-: 100 mEq/L (within the normal range)
    • HCO3-: 24 mEq/L (within the normal range)
    • PaCO2: 40 mmHg (within the normal range)
    • From these values, we can determine the likely metabolic abnormality. The low sodium (Na+) level suggests hyponatremia, which can occur in patients with renal failure. In this case, the patient has a concurrent high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Normal ABG: This option is incorrect because there is evidence of an abnormality in the ABG analysis (low sodium level).

Option B. Normal anion gap, metabolic acidosis: This option is incorrect because the anion gap is elevated in this case. The normal anion gap is associated with a chloride-based metabolic acidosis, which is not present here.

Option D. High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis: This option is incorrect because there is evidence of a metabolic acidosis in the ABG analysis (elevated anion gap).

questions.text: A patient with acute hepatitis B has recovered from the infection. Identify the serological marker marked in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anti-HBc Ab:

  •  Anti-HBc antibody refers to antibodies against the core antigen of the hepatitis B virus (HBV). The presence of anti-HBc antibodies indicates past or ongoing infection with HBV.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Anti-HBs Ab: This option refers to antibodies against the surface antigen of HBV. Anti-HBs antibodies develop after successful vaccination against HBV or as a result of resolving a previous HBV infection.

Option C - Anti-HBe Ab: Anti-HBe antibodies target the e antigen of HBV. The presence of anti-HBe antibodies typically indicates a transition from the acute phase of HBV infection to the recovery phase.

Option D - HBs Ag: This stands for hepatitis B surface antigen, which is a protein present on the surface of HBV. The presence of HBsAg indicates an active HBV infection.

questions.text: Which condition is frequently linked to Addison's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Autoimmune adrenalitis:

  • This is the correct answer. Addison's disease, also known as primary adrenal insufficiency, is commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis. In this condition, the body's immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys the adrenal cortex, leading to inadequate production of adrenal hormones.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Adrenocortical carcinoma - Adrenocortical carcinoma is a rare malignant tumor of the adrenal cortex. While it can cause adrenal hormone imbalances, it is not commonly associated with Addison's disease.

Option C - Hypernephroma - Hypernephroma is an outdated term for renal cell carcinoma, which is a type of kidney cancer. It is unrelated to Addison's disease.

Option D - Medullary carcinoma thyroid - Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is a type of thyroid cancer that arises from the parafollicular C cells. It is not associated with Addison's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of infection post-solid organ transplantation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cytomegalovirus (CMV):

  • CMV is a common viral infection that can cause significant complications in solid organ transplant recipients. It can affect multiple organ systems and lead to pneumonia, hepatitis, gastrointestinal disease, and other manifestations.

Incorrect Options:

  • Cytomegalovirus is more commonly seen in patients post solid organ transplantation, hence options B, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the treatment for hypercalcemia caused by vitamin D toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Dexamethasone:

  • Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid that can be used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity. It works by reducing intestinal calcium absorption and promoting renal calcium excretion.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Hydroxychloroquine: Hydroxychloroquine main uses are in the treatment of malaria and certain autoimmune disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.

Option C - Chloroquine: Similar to hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine is an antimalarial drug and is not commonly used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to vitamin D toxicity.

Option D - Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is primarily used in the treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text: An acute inflammatory response is not seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Apoptosis:

  • Apoptosis is a controlled and orderly process of programmed cell death.
  • It does not induce an acute inflammatory response but rather leads to the removal of dying cells by phagocytosis without provoking an intense immune response.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D can trigger an acute inflammatory response.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of liver failure ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B.

  • Paracetamol: Paracetamol overdose is the most common cause of acute liver failure, particularly in cases of intentional or accidental overdose. Paracetamol is metabolized in the liver, and high doses or overdose can overwhelm the liver's detoxification mechanisms, leading to liver damage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Alcohol: While alcohol abuse can lead to liver damage and cirrhosis, it is not the most common cause of acute liver failure. Chronic alcohol abuse can contribute to liver diseases such as alcoholic hepatitis and alcoholic cirrhosis.

Option C. CCI4 (carbon tetrachloride): CCI4 is a toxic chemical that was historically used as a solvent and industrial agent. Exposure to CCI4 can cause severe liver damage and hepatotoxicity, but it is not the most common cause of liver failure.

Option D. Pesticides: Pesticides can have hepatotoxic effects and contribute to liver damage in certain circumstances, such as occupational exposure or accidental ingestion. However, they are not the most common cause of liver failure.

questions.text: Which of the following are features of iron deficiency anaemia?

choices.text: TIBC increased, ferritin decreased, transferrin saturation increased
TIBC increased, soluble transferrin receptor decreased, ferritin increased
TIBC increased, transferrin saturation decreased, ferritin decreased
TIBC increased, transferrin saturation decreased, ferritin increased

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - TIBC increased, transferrin saturation decreased, ferritin decreased:

Iron Deficiency Anemia
Serum iron ↓
Total iron binding capacity ↑
Transferrin saturation ↓
Serum ferritin ↓
Soluble transferrin receptor ↑
Serum RBC protoporphyrin ↑

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following causes vasodilation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Histamine:

  • Histamine is a potent vasodilator released during allergic reactions and inflammation.
  • It acts on histamine receptors in blood vessel walls, causing relaxation of smooth muscle and resulting in vasodilation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thromboxane A2:

  • Thromboxane A2 is a vasoconstrictor and platelet aggregator.
  • It promotes platelet aggregation and constriction of blood vessels, leading to vasoconstriction rather than vasodilation.

Option C - Angiotensin II:

  • Angiotensin II is a vasoconstrictor that can cause the narrowing of blood vessels.

Option D - Leukotriene C4:

  • Leukotriene C4 is a pro-inflammatory mediator that is associated with vasoconstriction and bronchoconstriction.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis Jiroveci pneumonia. The flowcytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes 3 and 4) is shown below (Boxes 1 and 2 are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option C: Hyper IgM syndrome:

  • Hyper IgM syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a deficiency in the production of immunoglobulin class-switched antibodies (IgG, IgA, and IgE).
  • Patients with hyper IgM syndrome have normal or elevated levels of IgM but low levels or absence of other antibody classes.
  • The flow cytometry analysis showing elevated IgM levels and low IgG levels supports the diagnosis of hyper IgM syndrome.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reactions are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IgE-mediated:

  • Anaphylactoid reactions are not mediated by IgE antibodies.
  • Unlike true anaphylaxis, anaphylactoid reactions are triggered by non-immunologic mechanisms, such as the direct activation of mast cells or the complement system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Involves degranulation of mast cells:

  • Anaphylactoid reactions involve the rapid release of mediators, such as histamine, from mast cells and basophils.
  • These mediators cause symptoms similar to those seen in anaphylaxis, but anaphylactoid reactions are not IgE-mediated.

Option C - Can occur on first exposure:

  • Anaphylactoid reactions can occur on the first exposure to a triggering agent.
  • Unlike some allergic reactions that require sensitization and previous exposure, anaphylactoid reactions can happen without prior exposure or sensitization.

Option D - Can be caused by NSAIDs:

  • NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) can potentially trigger anaphylactoid reactions, but they are not the most common cause.
  • Anaphylactoid reactions can be caused by various substances, such as certain drugs (e.g., contrast media), radiocontrast dyes, intravenous fluids, and some food additives.
  • It is important to note that anaphylactoid reactions to NSAIDs are not IgE-mediated but rather due to direct activation of mast cells.

questions.text: Which of the following about γδ T-cells is incorrect?

choices.text: Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin
Need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Need antigen processing and presentation for its recognition

Explanation:

  • αβ T-cells and γδ T-cells do not require antigen processing and presentation by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules for recognition.
  • They can recognize and respond to antigens directly, including certain stress-induced molecules and microbial products.

Incorrect Options:

Kills extracellular bacteria by granulysin and perforin (Option A):

  • γδ T-cells can kill extracellular bacteria through the release of granulysin and perforin, which are cytotoxic molecules.

Direct killing of infected macrophages (Option C):

  • γδ T-cells can directly kill infected macrophages, which helps in the control of intracellular infections.

Provide protection against mycobacteria (Option D):

  • γδ T-cells have been shown to provide protection against mycobacterial infections, including Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of tuberculosis.
  • They contribute to the immune response by producing cytokines and exerting cytotoxic effects.

questions.text: Ciliocytophthoria is most commonly seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Acute respiratory infection:

  • Ciliocytophthoria refers to the presence of ciliated respiratory epithelial cells with cytoplasmic vacuoles containing inhaled particles, such as bacteria, viruses, or debris.
  • It is commonly observed in respiratory infections, particularly those affecting the lower respiratory tract.

Incorrect Options:

  • Ciliocytophthoria can be seen in options B, C, and D but is not specific to these conditions.

questions.text: Basophils are activated by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - IL-5:

  • Basophils, along with eosinophils and mast cells, are activated by IL-5, which is an interleukin involved in the regulation of immune responses, particularly in allergic reactions and parasitic infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - INF-gamma: INF-gamma primarily activates macrophages and plays a role in cellular immune responses.

Option C - TNF-alpha: TNF-alpha is a cytokine produced by activated macrophages and other immune cells.

Option D - IL-2: IL-2 stimulates the proliferation and activation of T-cells and natural killer (NK) cells.

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Divalent metal transporter-1:

  • Divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT-1) is the transporter responsible for the uptake of various divalent metals, including iron, across the apical membrane of enterocytes.
  • It plays a crucial role in the absorption of dietary iron from the intestinal lumen into the enterocyte.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ferroportin: Ferroportin is a protein involved in the export of iron from cells, including the export of iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream.

Option C - Divalent metal transporter-2: Divalent metal transporter-2 (DMT-2) is primarily involved in the transport of manganese and other divalent metals.

Option D - Haptocorrin: Haptocorrin (also known as transcobalamin I) is a protein involved in the transport of vitamin B12 in the body.

questions.text: Berry aneurysm occurs due to?

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B.

  • Arterial internal elastic lamina defect: This option is correct. Berry aneurysms, also known as intracranial or saccular aneurysms, are localized outpouchings or dilations of blood vessels in the brain. The primary underlying cause is a defect in the arterial internal elastic lamina, which weakens the vessel wall and predisposes it to aneurysm formation.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN: This option is incorrect. While hypertension (HTN) can contribute to the weakening of blood vessels over time, it is not the primary cause of berry aneurysms. HTN can increase the risk of rupture in a pre-existing aneurysm, but it does not directly lead to the formation of berry aneurysms.

Option C. Endothelial layer defect: This option is incorrect. While defects in the endothelial layer can contribute to vascular diseases, they are not the primary cause of berry aneurysms. The structural defect in the arterial internal elastic lamina is the main factor involved in the development of berry aneurysms.

Option D. Adventitia defect: This option is incorrect. The adventitia is the outermost layer of blood vessels and plays a role in providing structural support. However, a defect in the adventitia is not the primary cause of berry aneurysms. The defect in the arterial internal elastic lamina is the main factor contributing to the formation of these aneurysms.

questions.text: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other than nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Fabry’s disease:

  • Fabry's disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency or dysfunction of the enzyme alpha-galactosidase A.
  • This leads to the accumulation of a lipid called globotriaosylceramide (Gb3) within various cells and tissues, including the kidneys.
  • One of the characteristic findings in the urinalysis of patients with Fabry's disease is the presence of Maltese cross casts, also known as "corneal-shaped" or "glycolipid" casts.
  • These casts are formed by the precipitation of Gb3 within the renal tubules. They appear as refractile, yellowish-brown structures with a cross-like pattern when viewed under polarized light.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are not associated with the presence of Maltese cross crystals in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the use of the instrument given in the image below?

choices.text: Procedure cannot be done in both lateral and prone positions
Diagnosing an infiltrate or granulomatous disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Contraindicated if coagulopathy:

  • The given image is of a bone marrow biopsy needle.
  • Performing a bone marrow biopsy is contraindicated in cases where coagulopathy is present.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Breath holding is required:

  • Breath holding is not required during a bone marrow biopsy.
  • The procedure involves the insertion of a needle into the bone marrow cavity to obtain a sample, and patients are usually instructed to lie still and cooperate to minimize movement during the procedure.

Option C - Procedure cannot be done in both lateral and prone positions:

  • A bone marrow biopsy can be performed with the patient in either a lateral or prone position.
  • The choice of position depends on the preference of the physician and patient comfort.

Option D - Diagnosing an infiltrate or granulomatous disease:

  • A bone marrow biopsy is a diagnostic procedure used to evaluate various conditions, including hematologic disorders, metastatic cancer, infections, and bone marrow failure syndromes.
  • While an infiltrate or granulomatous disease may be detected through a bone marrow biopsy, it is not specific to this procedure alone.

questions.text: Hepcidin acts on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B.

  • Ferroportin: Ferroportin is an iron exporter protein found on the surface of cells, including enterocytes in the intestine. Hepcidin binds to ferroportin and induces its internalization and degradation. This leads to a decrease in iron export from the enterocyte into the plasma, thereby reducing iron absorption and availability.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Transferrin Transferrin is a protein that binds to iron in the plasma and facilitates its transport. Hepcidin does not directly bind to transferrin. Instead, hepcidin regulates iron levels by binding to ferroportin.

Option C. Ferritin Ferritin is an intracellular protein that stores iron. Hepcidin does not directly bind to ferritin. Instead, hepcidin regulates iron levels by modulating the activity of ferroportin, which in turn affects iron release from ferritin.

Option D. Divalent metal transporter 1 Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1) is a transmembrane protein responsible for the uptake of iron from the lumen of the intestine into enterocytes. Hepcidin does not bind to DMT1. Its main target is ferroportin, which is involved in the release of iron from the enterocyte into the bloodstream.

questions.text: The mutations / changes that convert proto-oncogene to oncogene include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Enhancer deletion:

  • Enhancer deletion is not a mechanism that directly converts a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.
  • Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences that enhance the transcription of genes.
  • While enhancer mutations can contribute to gene dysregulation, they do not directly convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Promoter insertion:

  • Promoter insertion is a genetic alteration that can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.
  • When a promoter sequence is inserted near a proto-oncogene, it can lead to increased and unregulated expression of the gene, promoting cell growth and division.

Option C - Gene amplification:

  • Gene amplification refers to an increase in the number of copies of a specific gene.
  • If a proto-oncogene undergoes amplification, it results in an increased dosage of the gene product, leading to abnormal cell proliferation and potentially converting it to an oncogene.

Option D - Point mutation:

  • Point mutations, which are single nucleotide changes in the DNA sequence, can convert a proto-oncogene to an oncogene.
  • Point mutations can result in altered protein function, increased protein stability, or constitutive activation of signalling pathways, promoting uncontrolled cell growth and division.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in SCID?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - BTK:

  • BTK is involved in X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by the absence or significantly reduced levels of mature B cells.
  • Mutations in the BTK gene impair B cell development and function, leading to a lack of antibody production.
  • XLA is not considered severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - JAK-3:

  • Mutations in the JAK-3 gene can cause severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • JAK-3 is involved in the signalling pathway of certain cytokines important for immune cell development and function.
  • Loss-of-function mutations in JAK-3 disrupt the development of T cells, B cells, and natural killer (NK) cells, resulting in SCID.

Option C - RAG1:

  • Mutations in the RAG1 gene can cause severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • RAG1 is crucial for the rearrangement of immunoglobulin and T cell receptor genes during lymphocyte development.
  • Loss-of-function mutations in RAG1 impair the development of functional T and B cells, leading to SCID.

Option D - IL-7Rα:

  • Mutations in the IL-7Rα gene can cause severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID).
  • IL-7Rα is a subunit of the receptor for interleukin-7, a cytokine involved in the development and survival of T cells.
  • Defects in IL-7Rα lead to impaired T cell development, resulting in SCID.

questions.text: You are doing an emergency laparotomy for a case of intestinal obstruction. Which organ will you first visualize to know if this is a case of small bowel or large bowel obstruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Caecum:

  • The caecum is the first part of the large intestine or colon.
  • During a laparotomy, when examining the caecum:
    • If the caecum is distended, it indicates the obstruction is beyond the caecum.
    • If the caecum is collapsed, it suggests the patient is experiencing small bowel obstruction.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Choose from the following the typical trigger for thyroid storm following thyroidectomy:

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Inadequate patient preparation:

  • Inadequate patient preparation, such as insufficient control of thyroid hormone levels before surgery, can contribute to the occurrence of thyroid storm. Patients with poorly controlled hyperthyroidism or Graves' disease are at a higher risk of developing thyroid storm during or after thyroidectomy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rough handling of thyroid during surgery: While rough handling of the thyroid during surgery can potentially cause complications such as bleeding or damage to surrounding structures, it is not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm refers to a life-threatening condition characterized by an exaggerated hypermetabolic state, and it is typically related to the release of excessive thyroid hormones into the bloodstream.

Option B - Due to parathyroid gland: The parathyroid glands are small glands located near the thyroid gland. Their primary function is to regulate calcium levels in the body. While complications related to the parathyroid glands can occur during thyroid surgery, they are not the usual cause of thyroid storm. Thyroid storm is specifically associated with the overproduction of thyroid hormones, not parathyroid hormone.

Option D - Infections: Infections, such as surgical site infections, can be a complication of thyroid surgery. However, they are not typically associated with the development of thyroid storm. Infections may cause local symptoms and complications but are not the primary cause of the systemic hypermetabolic state seen in thyroid storm.

questions.text: Calculate the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of a patient admitted after a road traffic accident who is currently on mechanical ventilation, but is able to open his eyes in response to a verbal command and spontaneously moves all four limbs.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6:

  • The patient is able to open their eyes spontaneously (Eyes-3).
  • The patient is unable to provide a verbal response due to being on mechanical ventilation, so it's marked as non-testable (Verbal-NT).
  • The patient spontaneously moves all four limbs, indicating a purposeful response to stimuli (Motor-6).

Incorrect Options:

Option A , B & D are incorrect ,refer to the explanation of correct option and learning outcome

questions.text: What is the tool utilized for the evaluation of wound infection severity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Southampton grading:

  • The Southampton grading system is a commonly used system for grading wound infections.
  • It classifies wound infections into four grades based on clinical signs such as pain, erythema (redness), edema (swelling), discharge, and systemic symptoms.
  • The grading system helps categorize wound infections into different levels of severity and guides appropriate management and treatment decisions.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - ASA classification: The ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) classification is a system used to assess the physical status of patients before surgery.

Option B - SIRS criteria: The SIRS (Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome) criteria are used to identify patients who may have a systemic inflammatory response.

Option D - APACHE II score: The APACHE II (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation II) score is a scoring system used to assess the severity of illness in critically ill patients

questions.text: On the 5th postoperative day post CABG, the patient develops tachypnea and hypotension. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acute respiratory failure:

  • Acute respiratory failure refers to a condition in which the lungs fail to provide adequate oxygenation to the body or efficiently remove carbon dioxide. Tachypnea (rapid breathing) and hypotension can be signs of inadequate oxygenation and perfusion. After CABG, potential causes of acute respiratory failure can include atelectasis (collapsed lung), pneumonia, pulmonary embolism, or other complications affecting lung function. Prompt evaluation and intervention are crucial to address respiratory compromise.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sepsis: Sepsis is a severe systemic infection that can cause various symptoms, including tachypnea and hypotension. However, without additional information, it is less likely to be the most probable cause on the 5th postoperative day after CABG. Other signs such as fever, elevated white blood cell count, or evidence of infection would be important to consider for a definitive diagnosis of sepsis.

Option B - Acute kidney failure: Acute kidney failure, also known as acute renal failure, primarily affects kidney function and may manifest as decreased urine output, fluid overload, electrolyte disturbances, or changes in laboratory parameters such as elevated creatinine levels. While it can cause hypotension, tachypnea is not a typical symptom of acute kidney failure. Therefore, it is less likely to be the most probable cause in this scenario.

Option D - Acute cardiac failure: Acute cardiac failure, also known as acute heart failure or congestive heart failure, typically presents with symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, fluid retention, and signs of poor cardiac output. While acute cardiac failure can cause hypotension, tachypnea alone is less commonly associated with this condition. Other cardiac symptoms, such as edema, jugular venous distention, or abnormal heart sounds, would be important to consider for a definitive diagnosis of acute cardiac failure.

questions.text: The most commonly involved artery in pseudoaneurysm formation:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Femoral artery:

  • The femoral artery is a common location for pseudoaneurysm formation. It is a large artery located in the groin area and is frequently accessed for arterial catheterization or invasive procedures such as angiography, cardiac catheterization, or arterial line placement. Pseudoaneurysms can occur as a complication of these procedures due to the puncture and subsequent incomplete closure of the artery, leading to the formation of a pulsating hematoma.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Aorta: While the aorta can develop aneurysms, a pseudoaneurysm, also known as a false aneurysm, is less commonly associated with the aorta. 

Option C - Popliteal artery: The popliteal artery is located behind the knee and is also susceptible to pseudoaneurysm formation. However, compared to the femoral artery, pseudoaneurysms in the popliteal artery are less common. Popliteal artery pseudoaneurysms can occur due to trauma, iatrogenic injury, or underlying vascular diseases affecting the artery.

Option D - None of the above: This option is incorrect as both the femoral artery (Option B) and the popliteal artery (Option C) can be involved in pseudoaneurysm formation, with the femoral artery being the more commonly involved artery.

questions.text: What is the most effective approach for treating the wound depicted in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cleaning and dressing:

  • Abrasions are superficial skin injuries that typically involve the removal of the epidermal layer.
  • The initial management of an abrasion involves cleaning the wound thoroughly with a mild antiseptic solution or sterile saline to reduce the risk of infection.
  • After cleaning, applying a sterile dressing helps protect the wound from contamination and provides a moist environment that promotes healing.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Debridement and dressing: Debridement is the removal of dead, damaged, or contaminated tissue from a wound. While debridement may be necessary for deep or contaminated wounds, it is not typically required for simple abrasions.

Option C - Cleaning and skin grafting: Skin grafting is generally not indicated for simple abrasions. Skin grafting is commonly used for larger wounds, burns, or wounds with exposed underlying structures that require coverage to facilitate healing.

Option D - Cleaning and use of allograft: While allografts can be used in certain wound management scenarios, such as deep or chronic wounds, they are not commonly utilized for simple abrasions.

questions.text: After performing a diagnostic laparoscopy in a child with a unilateral undescended testis revealing blind-ending testicular vessels on the right side, what is the subsequent course of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Nothing to be done:

  • If blind-ending testicular vessels are seen during laparoscopy, it indicates the absence or atrophy of the testis on the right side. In such cases, there is no further intervention required as the finding suggests that no viable testis is present. However, it is important to document the absence or atrophy of the testis and discuss the findings with the patient and their family.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Inguinal exploration: Inguinal exploration involves surgical exploration of the inguinal canal to locate and bring down the undescended testis. However, in this scenario, if blind-ending testicular vessels are seen on the right side during laparoscopy, it indicates that the testis is absent or atrophic (non-functional). Inguinal exploration would not be beneficial in such cases since there is no testis to bring down.

Option B - Abdominal exploration: Abdominal exploration refers to further surgical exploration within the abdomen to locate the undescended testis. However, if blind-ending testicular vessels are visualized during laparoscopy, it suggests the absence or atrophy of the testis. Additional abdominal exploration would not change this finding and would not be necessary.

Option C - Scrotal exploration: Scrotal exploration involves surgical exploration of the scrotum to locate the undescended testis. However, if blind-ending testicular vessels are observed during laparoscopy, it suggests the absence or atrophy of the testis. Scrotal exploration would not yield a different outcome since the testis is not present or non-functional.

questions.text: Which of the options provided is not considered a part of qSOFA?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bilateral pupillary reflex:

  • This is not a component of the qSOFA score. The qSOFA score focuses on clinical signs that are easily and quickly accessible at the bedside to identify patients at risk of poor outcomes in the context of suspected infection.
  • It consists of three criteria: respiratory rate ≥ 22/min, altered mental status, and systolic blood pressure ≤ 100 mm Hg. If a patient meets two or more of these criteria, it suggests a higher risk of poor outcomes.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min: This is a component of the qSOFA (quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment) score..

Option B - Systolic BP ≤ 100 mm Hg: This is also a component of the qSOFA score.

Option C - Altered mental status: Altered mental status is another component of the qSOFA score.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of SIRS?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Respiratory Rate > 20/minute and PaCO2 < 35 mmHg:

  • SIRS is diagnosed when at least two of the four parameters are present. Among the options provided, Option 2 is incorrect because it mentions a respiratory rate greater than 20/minute and PaCO2 less than 35 mmHg. However, SIRS criteria do not include specific PaCO2 values; it focuses solely on respiratory rate.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Temperature > 38 degrees Celsius:

  • This option suggests a temperature above 38 degrees Celsius, which is consistent with one of the parameters for diagnosing SIRS.

Option C - Pulse rate > 90/minute:

  • A pulse rate exceeding 90/minute aligns with the criteria for diagnosing SIRS.

Option D - WBC > 12000/mm3 or < 4000/mm3:

  • An elevated or decreased white blood cell count falls within the parameters for

questions.text: Which nerve is typically affected when patients experience loss of sensation while shaving after parotidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Great auricular nerve:

  • The great auricular nerve is a sensory branch of the cervical plexus (specifically, from the C2 and C3 spinal nerves).
  • It provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid region, including the area below the ear and the angle of the mandible.
  • During parotidectomy, the great auricular nerve can be affected or injured, leading to loss of sensation in the corresponding area, which can manifest as decreased sensation while shaving.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Auriculotemporal nerve: The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve, does not cause sensation loss during shaving post-parotidectomy as it mainly supplies sensation to the temporal region and external ear.

Option C - Facial nerve: The facial nerve controls facial muscle movement, not sensation. While it's manipulated during parotidectomy, shaving sensation loss isn't typically linked to it; other nerves like the great auricular nerve are more relevant.

Option D - Mandibular nerve: The mandibular nerve, a division of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensation to the lower jaw and motor function to jaw muscles. Shaving sensation loss after parotidectomy isn't directly tied to it.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Unipolar cautery:

  • The image shows a unipolar cautery, which is an electrical surgical instrument used for cutting or coagulating tissue during surgical procedures. It consists of a handheld handle with an attached electrode that delivers electrical current to the target tissue.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Bipolar cautery: Unlike unipolar cautery, which requires a separate grounding pad, bipolar cautery uses forceps-like instruments with two electrodes to pass current directly between them.

Option C - Harmonic scalpel: The harmonic scalpel is a surgical tool that cuts and seals tissue using ultrasonic vibrations generated from electrical energy.

Option D - Ligasure: A vessel sealing system, seals blood vessels and tissue during surgery by applying bipolar energy through a generator and disposable tips.

questions.text: A patient comes with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following is not done?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Platelet transfusion:

  • Platelet transfusion is not typically done as a primary intervention for active variceal bleeding. Platelets are not directly involved in the clotting mechanism of variceal bleeding, which is primarily caused by increased portal pressure and vascular wall abnormalities.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Arrange pRBC: It aims to correct anemia and maintain hemodynamic stability by restoring blood volume and oxygen-carrying capacity.

Option C - IV Octreotide: It is a synthetic somatostatin analog that reduces splanchnic blood flow and inhibits the release of various vasoactive substances, including vasodilatory peptides.

Option D - Urgent Endoscopy: It allows for direct visualization of the bleeding site, identification of high-risk stigmata, and the application of endoscopic therapies, such as band ligation or sclerotherapy, to achieve hemostasis.

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument depicted below, which is utilized for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Veress needle:

  • The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create a pneumoperitoneum, which is the insufflation of carbon dioxide gas into the peritoneal cavity to create a working space during laparoscopic procedures.
  • The Veress needle is inserted through a small incision or through the umbilicus, and its tip is equipped with a spring-loaded mechanism that allows for controlled penetration of the abdominal wall. Once inserted, carbon dioxide gas is introduced through the needle to inflate the peritoneal cavity.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect because Morris' needle is for vasectomy, Yankauer suction tip is for suctioning, and Von Graefe needle is for ophthalmic surgery, respectively, none related to pneumoperitoneum creation.

questions.text: Please assess the severity of the bedsore depicted in the provided image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stage 4:

  • In this stage, the bed sore (also known as a pressure ulcer or decubitus ulcer) exhibits full-thickness skin loss with extensive destruction, tissue necrosis, or damage to muscle, bone, or supporting structures.
  • The wound may have slough or eschar, and it can extend beyond the visible area. In stage 4, there is deep tissue involvement, and the ulcer is typically characterized by a large, open wound with significant tissue loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option B -  Stage 3: Full-thickness skin loss without deeper tissue involvement. May resemble deep craters, but no muscle or bone exposure.

Option C - Stage 2: Partial-thickness skin loss, shallow ulcers or blisters, reaching the dermis but not deeper layers.

Option D - Stage 1: Intact skin with non-blanchable redness, no open wounds or visible skin

questions.text: Which intravenous cannula is recommended for a patient who arrived at the emergency room following a road traffic accident and needs a significant volume of fluids to be administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Grey:

  • The grey-colored IV cannula is specifically designed for high-flow rates. It has a larger gauge size, allowing for a faster and more efficient delivery of fluids.
  • The grey cannula is preferred in situations where a large amount of fluids needs to be transfused, such as in trauma cases or during resuscitation efforts.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Green: The green-colored IV cannula typically has a smaller gauge size and is suitable for moderate-flow rates.

Option B - Blue: The blue-colored IV cannula is commonly used for pediatric patients and for individuals with smaller veins. It is also suitable for moderate-flow rates.

Option C - Pink: The pink-colored IV cannula is typically used for neonatal patients and individuals with extremely small veins.

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Jackson-Pratt drain:

  • The Jackson-Pratt drain, also known as a JP drain, is a closed suction drainage system used to remove fluid, such as blood or serous fluid, from a surgical site.
  • It consists of a silicone or latex drain connected to a collection bulb. The drain is typically placed in the surgical site, and the bulb is compressed to create negative pressure, allowing for the continuous or intermittent drainage of fluid.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Hemovac:

  • The Hemovac drain, akin to the Jackson-Pratt drain, eliminates fluids via a plastic reservoir connected to a tube with a compressible bulb, utilizing suction through bulb compression.

Option C - Minivac: There is no commonly recognized surgical drain known as the "Minivac." It is not a recognized instrument for drainage purposes.

Option D - Corrugated drain: A corrugated rubber drain is a flexible tube with ribbed surface, used for drainage in medical procedures. It differs from the Jackson-Pratt drain in structure and operation.

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species:

choices.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India
Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria
Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax:

  • The invasion of red cells by merozoites requires specific glycoprotein receptors, i.e., Duffy blood group antigen, to invade red blood cells. Individuals who lack this antigen are generally resistant to P. vivax infection, while those who have it are susceptible to the parasite.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Drug-resistant falciparum is seen in India: Drug-resistant Plasmodium falciparum, the most virulent species of malaria, is indeed seen in India.

Option C - Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria: Algid malaria is characterized by peripheral circulatory failure, rapid thready pulse with low blood pressure, and cold, clammy skin. There may be severe abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and profound shock.

Option D - Relapse is seen in P. Ovale: Relapse is a unique characteristic of Plasmodium ovale and vivax infection. After the initial infection is treated, the parasite can remain dormant in the liver and cause relapses of malaria symptoms months or even years later.

questions.text: In a case of chronic allergy, which immunoglobulin demonstrates increased levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IgE:

  • IgE is the immunoglobulin that plays a central role in allergic reactions. It is responsible for triggering the release of histamine and other inflammatory substances in response to an allergen. Elevated levels of IgE are commonly seen in individuals with chronic allergies and are associated with conditions like allergic rhinitis, asthma, and atopic dermatitis.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - IgA: IgA is primarily involved in local or mucosal immunityand provides protection against pathogens by cross-linking bigger antigens with multiple epitopes and preventing entry through mucosal surface.

Option B - IgM: IgM is the first antibody produced in response to an infection and is the most potent activator of complement pathway.

Option D - IgG: IgG provides immunity to the fetus and newborn, mediates precipitation and neutralization reactions, and activates complement pathway.

questions.text: Which among the following occupations is a risk factor for this presenting illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Kennel Worker:

  • The reddish serpiginous tunnels in the epidermis, as shown in the image, are suggestive of Cutaneous larva migrans caused by Ancylostoma braziliense. 
  • Kennel workers who handle and care for animals, including dogs and cats, are at an increased risk of exposure to the larvae of hookworms (Ancylostoma braziliense), which can cause cutaneous larva migrans (CLM). Ancylostoma braziliensis is transmitted by the larva which penetrates the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Kennel workers are at maximum risk of developing cutaneous larva migrans.

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sporothrix Schenckii:

  • Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous fungal infection. Sporotrichosis typically presents as nodules or ulcers along the lymphatic channels and is commonly acquired through traumatic inoculation of the fungus, such as by thorns or splinters.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cryptococcus Neoformans: Cryptococcus neoformans is a fungal pathogen primarily associated with respiratory and central nervous system infections in immunocompromised individuals. It is classified as an opportunistic infection.

Option B - Histoplasma Capsulatum: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes histoplasmosis. Histoplasmosis is an intracellular infection of the reticuloendothelial system. It is classified under systemic mycoses.

Option D - Talaromyces Marneffei: It is a dimorphic fungus that causes opportunistic infections in an individual infected with AIDS. It causes a disseminated infection with multiple organ involvement. It is classified as an opportunistic infection.

questions.text: Mw vaccine is extracted from which bacteria, mentioned below :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - M. indicus Pranii:

  • M. indicus pranii: Mw vaccine, also known as the Mw immunotherapeutic vaccine, is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii. It is a heat-killed whole-cell preparation of this non-pathogenic mycobacterium.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - M. Ulcerans: M. ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer, which produces exotoxin myolactone.

Option C - M. Leprae: M. leprae is the causative agent of leprosy, not used for the production of the Mw vaccine.

Option D - M. Bovis: M. bovis is a pathogenic bacterium that causes bovine tuberculosis. It is not involved in the production of the Mw vaccine.

questions.text: The toxin produced by the organism shown below acts via ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - ADP ribosylation of EF2:

  • The gram staining shows gram-positive bacilli with a characteristic appearance resembling a Chinese letter (V or L shaped) or cuneiform arrangement, and the ends show metachromatic granules, giving it a club-shaped appearance suggestive of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, known as diphtheria toxin, acts by ADP ribosylation of EF2.
  • It is a bipartite. Fragment B helps in binding, and fragment A inhibits polypeptide chain elongation in the presence of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide, inactivating the elongation factor EF-2.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increase in cAMP: This mechanism is associated with toxins such as cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, not the toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Option B - Increase in cGMP: This mechanism is associated with toxins such as heat-stable enterotoxins of E. coli.

Option D - 60s ribosome: This mechanism is associated with toxins such as Shiga toxin and verocytotoxin.

questions.text: Identify the media?
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

B. CLED  - the given image is of CLED agar

Explanation:

  • CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte-Deficient) medium is commonly used for the culture of urine specimens to isolate and identify microorganisms causing urinary tract infections (UTIs).

  • Lactose Fermentation Differentiation: CLED medium contains lactose as a carbohydrate source. Lactose-fermenting bacteria produce acid during the fermentation of lactose, leading to a change in the pH of the medium. This change in pH results in a color change of the indicator in the medium. Lactose-fermenting colonies appear yellow, while non–lactose fermenters appear pink or red.

Now, let's discuss the other options:

  1. Nutrient agar - this option is incorrect

    3.     Nutrient agar: This option is incorrect

    4 Blood Agar: this option is incorrect

questions.text: All of the following can be seen intracellularly in hepatocytes except.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Babesia:

  • Babesia species are tick-borne parasites that primarily infect red blood cells. Sporozoites in the salivary gland of the ticks are transmitted to humans after bite and enters bloodstream. They change to trophozoites, invade red blood cells, and multiply asexually. Newly formed trophozoites are released by rupturing erythrocytes and invade new erythrocytes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Toxoplasma: The tachyzoites of T. gondii formed in the intestine can infect the brain, eye, liver, spleen, lung, and skeletal muscles and form tissue cysts.

Option B - Plasmodium: Plasmodium species are the causative agents of malaria. The pre-erythrocytic schizogony takes place in the liver.

Option D - Leishmania: The amastigote of the Leishmania donovani multiply enormously in the macrophages of the liver, bone marrow, and spleen.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about influenza ?

choices.text: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine is used
5-12 years is a high risk group

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 5-12 years is a High Risk Group:

  • The high-risk groups for severe complications of influenza typically include young children (especially those under 2 years), the elderly (65 years and older), pregnant women, individuals with underlying health conditions, and immunocompromised individuals. The age group of 5-12 years is generally considered to have a lower risk compared to these high-risk groups.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intranasal Live attenuated vaccine is used: Intranasal live attenuated vaccine, a trivalent vaccine H1N1 (A), H3N2 (A), type B is indicated for individuals with influenza infection, contraindicated in low immunity.

Option C - Aquatic birds act as reservoir: Aquatic birds, particularly wild waterfowl, are considered the natural reservoir for influenza viruses. They can carry different strains of influenza viruses, including avian influenza viruses, without showing symptoms. These viruses can occasionally cross over to infect other species, including humans.

Option D - Secondary attack rate is 5-15%: The secondary attack rate refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop the disease after being exposed to an infected individual. In the case of influenza, the secondary attack rate can vary depending on factors such as the specific strain, population density, and level of immunity. Generally, the secondary attack rate for influenza is estimated to be around 5 to 15%.

questions.text: Which of the following is a xenodiagnostic method ?

choices.text: Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC
Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue
Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis
Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Injecting Aedes thorax with blood of a patient with suspected dengue:

  • In the Xenodiagnostic method, arthropod vectors are fed on infected patients for 2-4 weeks, after which the vectors are examined for parasite presence.
  • It involves injecting the thorax of Aedes mosquitoes (the vector for dengue virus) with blood from a patient suspected to have dengue. The mosquitoes are then observed for viral replication and transmission, which can help confirm the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rabbit ileal loop assay for ETEC: It is not a xenodiagnostic method as it does not involve the use of a vector and the organism is being detected for the disease is bacteria.

Option C - Injecting a hamster with splenic biopsy for diagnosis of leishmaniasis: This is not a xenodiagnostic method as the vector for leishmaniasis is sandfly.

Option D - Intradermal test on guinea pigs for toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheria: This is not a xenodiagnostic method as it does not involve the use of a vector, and the organism is being detected for the disease is bacteria.

questions.text: The following lesion is seen in a 25 year old man who came to a primary health center 5 days after he had unprotected sexual intercourse. On palpation the ulcers were painful. Suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy was present on the right side. The patient has no previous history of drug allergy. Which kit will be used for the management of this particular sexually transmitted disease ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Kit 3/white:
