  •  Kit 3/white: This kit is the correct choice for the management of the presented sexually transmitted disease. The details provided in the question, such as the presence of painful ulcers and suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy, suggest a possible diagnosis of chancroid.
  • Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. Treatment typically involves antibiotic therapy, and Kit 3/white is the appropriate kit for managing this condition.

 

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B & D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which cell is absent from the layer indicated as D?
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: D 

  • Langerhans cells: Langerhans cells are specialized immune cells present in the epidermis. They play a role in immune surveillance and antigen presentation. Langerhans cells are typically found in the more superficial layers of the epidermis, particularly in the stratum spinosum layer. Therefore, Langerhans cells are not present in the marked stratum basale layer. This option is correct.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Keratinocyte: Keratinocytes are the predominant cells in the epidermis and are responsible for producing the protein keratin, which contributes to the strength and waterproofing of the skin. Keratinocytes are present in the stratum basale layer, so they are indeed present in the marked layer. This option is incorrect.

Option B. Merkel cell: Merkel cells are specialized sensory cells found in the skin that play a role in touch sensation. They are typically found in the stratum basale layer, forming connections with nerve endings. Therefore, Merkel cells are present in the marked layer. This option is incorrect.

Option C. Melanocyte: Melanocytes are pigment-producing cells responsible for the production of melanin, which gives color to the skin, hair, and eyes. Melanocytes are primarily located in the stratum basale layer and extend their processes into the surrounding layers. Based on the image, it is not possible to determine the presence of melanocytes in the marked layer. This option is inconclusive.

questions.text: When should you schedule the removal of the patch test for an 8-year-old boy who has a previous diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B -72 hours:

  • 72 hours: This is the recommended timeframe for patch removal. It allows sufficient time for allergic reactions to occur and helps ensure accurate interpretation of the test results.
  • Contact dermatitis is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction, which can take a few days to appear. Therefore, it is important that a person does a patch test for 96 hours before using new products fully.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 24 hours: This is too early for patch removal. Allergic reactions may take some time to develop, and 24 hours may not be sufficient for a reaction to manifest.

Option C - 48 Hours:  can be correct , but 72 hours is the upper limit , so better answer.

Option D - 96 hours: This is beyond the recommended timeframe for patch removal. By 96 hours, the patch may have already been on the patient's skin for too long, increasing the risk of skin irritation or adverse reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Zoster (shingles):

  • Zoster (shingles) - Zoster is characterized by a painful rash that typically develops into fluid-filled blisters.
  • The rash follows a dermatomal distribution, typically appearing as a band or stripe on one side of the body. It is not typically maculopapular in nature.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rubella:  Rubella, also known as German measles, presents with a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body.

Option C - Dengue: During the febrile phase of dengue, a maculopapular rash may be present.

Option D - Measles: Measles, also known as rubeola, presents with a characteristic maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body.

questions.text: A 10 year old child presents with hair loss. The hair loss is patchy as shown in the image below.  Which off the following types of tinea is this child suffering from ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ectothrix:

  • Ectothrix is a type of tinea capitis where the fungal infection primarily affects the outer layer of the hair shaft. This results in hair becoming brittle, breaking off at the surface of the scalp, and causing patchy hair loss.
  • In Ectothrix infections, the fungus can often be seen surrounding the hair shaft on microscopy.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Endothrix:

  • In Endothrix infections, the fungus is found inside the hair shaft and doesn't typically cause hair breakage or patchy hair loss.

Option C - Kerion:

  • Kerion is a severe type of fungal infection of the scalp characterized by painful, boggy, inflamed, and pus-filled nodules or plaques.

Option D - Favus:

  • Favus is a specific type of tinea capitis caused by the fungus Trichophyton schoenleinii. It results in the formation of yellow, cup-shaped crusts on the scalp, along with hair loss.

questions.text: The test given below in the image is used for :
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Stereopsis test:

  • The test shown in the image is Titmus stereotest, used for assessing stereopsis, which is the ability to perceive depth and three-dimensional vision
  • The Titmus test is a three-dimensional polarized vectograph that comprises two plates presented in a booklet. To take the test, one needs to wear polarized spectacles before viewing the plates.
  • The right plate shows a large fly, which tests for gross stereopsis, while the left plate shows nine squares, each containing four circles and animals. The test should be taken at a distance of 40 cm.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: After the uneventful placement of an intraocular lens in a young patient during cataract surgery, what further steps should be taken?

choices.text:
Relaced when secondary cataract develops

Replaced when presbyopia develops

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

  • Never replaced: In most cases, the IOL does not need to be replaced unless there are complications or issues with the lens. Modern IOLs are designed to be permanent and durable, and they can last a lifetime without causing any problems.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. IOL replaced every 10 years: There is no fixed time interval for replacing the IOL unless there are complications or specific indications for its replacement. Routine replacement every 10 years is not necessary.

Option C. Replaced when secondary cataract develops: Secondary cataract, also known as posterior capsule opacification, can occur after cataract surgery. It is a common complication where the posterior capsule, which holds the IOL in place, becomes cloudy. In such cases, a laser procedure called YAG capsulotomy can be performed to clear the visual axis and restore clear vision, without replacing the IOL itself.

Option D. Replaced when presbyopia develops: Presbyopia is a natural age-related condition that affects near vision. It occurs due to the loss of flexibility in the natural lens of the eye, not the IOL. If presbyopia develops after cataract surgery, other options such as glasses, contact lenses, or additional surgical procedures like monovision correction may be considered, but replacing the IOL is not typically necessary.

questions.text: What is the correct information about the image provided below?

choices.text: It is called Argyl Robertson pupil

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Seen in optic neuritis:

  • The image represents the relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) characterized by weak pupillary response of the diseased and brisk response by the normal eye seen in incomplete optic nerve lesion (optic neuritis) or severe retinal disease (rhegmatogenous retinal detachment). The difference between the two pupillary reactions is highlighted by the swinging flash test.
  • The image reveals the following findings:
    • Both pupils dilated without the flash light.
    • Both pupils contract when light is flashed to the left eye i.e., normal eye.
    • Both pupils show paradoxical dilatation when light is flashed to the right eye, i.e., showing relative afferent pupillary defect.
    • Again both the pupils contract when light is flashed to the left eye i.e., normal eye.
    • Again both pupils show paradoxical dilatation when light is flashed to the right eye.

 

Incorrect Option: 

Option A - It is called Argyl Robertson pupil: Argyl Robertson pupil is seen in neurosyphilis, where the pupils shows positive accommodation reflex and absent light reflex,

Option B - Both eyes are abnormal: Left eye is normal and right eye is affected with optic nerve lesion.

Option C - Right eye is normal: An optic nerve lesion or severe retinal disease is associated with right eye resulting in RAPD.

questions.text: ETDRS study was related to
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diabetic macular edema:

  • The ETDRS (Early Treatment of Diabetic Retinopathy Study) study was primarily conducted to study the treatment options for diabetic macular edema, a common complication of diabetic retinopathy characterized by fluid accumulation in the macula.
  • Early Treatment of Diabetic Retinopathy
    • It classifies the diabetic retinopathy into
      • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
        • No DR
        • Very mild NPDR - Microaneurysm only
        • Mild NPDR - microaneurysms, retinal haemorrhages, exudates, cotton-wool spots
        • Moderate NPDR - Severe retinal haemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA, and venous beading in 1 quadrant.
        • Severe NPDR - One or more of severe haemorrhages in all 4 quadrants, significant venous beading in 2 or more quadrants
        • Very severe NPDR - Two or more of the criteria for severe NPDR.
    • PDR (Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy)
      • Mild-moderate PDR - New vessels on the disc (NVD) or new vessels elsewhere (NVE), but extent insufficient to meet the high-risk criteria.
      • High-risk PDR - NVD greater than ETDRS standard photograph 10A, with vitreous haemorrhage, and NVE greater than 2 disc area with vitreous haemorrhage.
      • Advanced diabetic eye disease - Vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment, and neovascular glaucoma.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. ETDRS study was conducted to study the treatment options for diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: All of the following are causes for expanding blind spots, except for...
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B

  • Hypoplasia of the optic disc: Hypoplasia refers to underdevelopment or incomplete development of the optic disc. This condition is present from birth and is characterized by a smaller size of the optic disc. While hypoplasia of the optic disc can lead to visual impairment, it is not typically associated with an expanding blind spot. Instead, it may cause other visual field defects or abnormalities.

Incorrect option: 

Option A. POAG (Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma): In POAG, there is progressive damage to the optic nerve, typically associated with elevated intraocular pressure. This damage can lead to visual field defects, including an expanding blind spot.

Option C. Papilledema: Papilledema is the swelling of the optic disc due to increased intracranial pressure. It can occur in conditions such as intracranial hypertension, brain tumors, or other causes of elevated pressure within the skull. Papilledema can cause visual disturbances and may lead to visual field defects, but it does not typically manifest as an expanding blind spot.

Option D. Medullated nerve fibers: Medullated nerve fibers are myelinated nerve fibers that may appear as bright white streaks on the retina. They are a benign finding and do not usually cause visual field defects or an expanding blind spot.

questions.text: Please identify the structure indicated by the arrow.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Choroid

  • The structure marked with arrow is the choroid
  • The choroid is a critical structure in the eye, part of the uveal tract, which also includes the ciliary body and the iris.
  • The main functions of the choroid are to provide oxygen and nutrients to the outer layers of the retina and to absorb scattered light, thereby reducing reflections within the eye.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Outer limiting membrane: The outer limiting membrane is a structure in the retina that separates the outer nuclear layer from the inner segments of the photoreceptor cells. It is formed by the junctions between the Müller cells and the photoreceptor cells. The red arrow in the image does not point to the outer limiting membrane.

Option B - Inner plexiform layer: The inner plexiform layer is a layer of the retina located between the inner nuclear layer and the ganglion cell layer. It contains synaptic connections between bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and ganglion cells.

Option D - Outer nuclear layer: The outer nuclear layer is a layer of the retina located between the outer plexiform layer and the external limiting membrane. It contains the cell bodies of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones).

questions.text: Which of the following processes does not occur in the direction from 5' to 3'?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - RNA editing:

  • RNA editing is a process that can modify the nucleotide sequence of RNA molecules after transcription. It can involve changes in bases, the addition or removal of nucleotides, or other modifications. While RNA editing can occur in different directions depending on the specific mechanism, it is not universally restricted to the 5' to 3' direction.
  • RNA polymerase begins moving down the DNA template strand in the 3' to 5' direction

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Transcription:

  • Transcription is the process of synthesizing RNA from a DNA template. It occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, meaning that the RNA molecule is synthesized in the same direction as the template DNA strand.

Option B - DNA replication:

  • DNA replication is the process of copying the DNA molecule to produce two identical DNA molecules. It also occurs in the 5' to 3' direction, where the new DNA strand is synthesized in the same direction as the template DNA strand.

Option C - DNA repair:

  • DNA repair mechanisms are responsible for fixing damaged DNA. Many DNA repair processes involve the removal and replacement of damaged nucleotides, which generally occur in the 5' to 3' direction. Therefore, DNA repair also occurs in the 5' to 3' direction.

questions.text: A body builder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pyruvate carboxylase:

  • Raw egg whites contain a protein called avidin, which can bind to biotin, a B-vitamin essential for the activity of pyruvate carboxylase. Biotin deficiency can, in turn, affect the function of pyruvate carboxylase, as well as other biotin-dependent enzymes.
  • Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme involved in the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, an important step in gluconeogenesis. Deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase can lead to impaired gluconeogenesis and energy production, which could contribute to fatigue during exercise. Therefore, this is the correct answer.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Glucose 6 phosphate: Deficiency of this enzyme can lead to a condition called glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency), which is not directly related to the body builder's symptoms of fatigue during exercise.

Option C - PEPCK: PEPCK (Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase)deficiency can affect gluconeogenesis and energy production, but it is not directly related to the body builder's symptoms in this scenario.

Option D - Glycogen phosphorylase: Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency can lead to glycogen storage diseases, but it is not directly related to the body builder's symptoms of fatigue during exercise in this context.

questions.text: Which modification will lead to a change in the biological activity of the hormone given in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Change in 29-30 in B chain:

  • Insulin undergoes post-translational modification, including the removal of a specific peptide called the C-peptide. A change in the amino acid sequence at positions 29-30 in the B chain could disrupt this processing, leading to altered biological activity.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Hydrolysis of disulfide bonds: Insulin is a peptide hormone that consists of two polypeptide chains, A and B, connected by disulfide bonds. Hydrolysis of these disulfide bonds would disrupt the structure of insulin, leading to a loss of biological activity.

Option B - Change in 5-6 in A chain: A change in the amino acid sequence at positions 5-6 in the A chain of insulin could potentially affect its structure and binding to insulin receptors. However, the specific impact on biological activity would depend on the nature of the amino acid change.

Option D - Change in 14-16 in A chain: A change in the amino acid sequence at positions 14-16 in the A chain of insulin could potentially affect its structure and binding to insulin receptors. However, the specific impact on biological activity would depend on the nature of the amino acid change.

questions.text: Which TCA cycle intermediate is involved in the metabolism of heme?
questions.solution:
Correct Ans. C

  • Succinyl CoA: Succinyl CoA is the correct answer. It is an intermediate in the TCA cycle and is directly involved in heme metabolism. It serves as a precursor for the synthesis of heme, which is an essential component of hemoglobin and other heme-containing proteins.

Incorrect Option:

Option A. Alpha-ketoglutarate: Alpha-ketoglutarate is an intermediate in the TCA (tricarboxylic acid) cycle, but it is not directly involved in heme metabolism. It participates in energy generation through the TCA cycle and is involved in amino acid metabolism.

Option B. Fumarate: Fumarate is also an intermediate in the TCA cycle, but it is not directly involved in heme metabolism. It is converted to malate in the TCA cycle.

Option D. Malate: Malate is an intermediate in the TCA cycle but is not directly involved in heme metabolism. It is converted to oxaloacetate, which then re-enters the TCA cycle.

questions.text: What is the specific type of genetic mutation observed in sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Point mutation:

  • Point mutation: A point mutation involves the substitution of a single nucleotide with another nucleotide. This can lead to a change in the corresponding amino acid in the protein sequence. In the case of sickle cell anemia, the point mutation is the substitution of Adenine with Thymine, resulting in the replacement of glutamic acid with valine, in the beta globin chain of hemoglobin.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Insertion: An insertion mutation involves the addition of extra nucleotides into the DNA sequence. This leads to a shift in the reading frame and often results in a frameshift mutation, which can have significant effects on the resulting protein. However, this is not the type of mutation seen in sickle cell anemia.

Option B - Deletion: A deletion mutation involves the removal of nucleotides from the DNA sequence. Similar to an insertion mutation, it can cause a frameshift mutation and alter the resulting protein. However, this is not the type of mutation seen in sickle cell anemia.

Option D - Frameshift mutations: Frameshift mutations occur due to insertions or deletions of nucleotides that cause a shift in the reading frame. This leads to significant changes in the resulting protein sequence. While frameshift mutations can occur in various genetic disorders, it is not the specific type of mutation seen in sickle cell anemia.

questions.text: What is the deficiency in a patient who exhibits the following features: -
questions.solution:
Correct Ans. B

  • Tryptophan Tryptophan deficiency can lead to pellagra, a condition characterized by a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). Pellagra can present with various symptoms, including dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and the characteristic Casal's necklace, which refers to a dark pigmentation around the neck.

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Phenylalanine Phenylalanine is also an essential amino acid, and its deficiency can lead to a condition called phenylketonuria (PKU). However, PKU does not manifest with the specific symptom of Casal's necklace.

Option C: Glutamine Glutamine is a non-essential amino acid, meaning it can be synthesized by the body. While glutamine deficiency can occur in certain situations, such as severe illness or malnutrition, it is not directly associated with the specific symptom of Casal's necklace.

Option D: Arginine Arginine is a semi-essential amino acid, meaning it can be produced by the body but may become essential in certain conditions, such as during periods of growth or illness. Arginine deficiency is rare and not typically associated with the characteristic symptom of Casal's necklace.

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product?
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Glutamine replaced by asparagine

  • Glutamine replaced by asparagine: This is the correct option. Glutamine (Gln) and asparagine (Asn) are both polar, uncharged amino acids with similar properties. Therefore, replacing glutamine with asparagine is a conservative substitution that is unlikely to significantly affect the structure or function of the protein.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Glutamine replaced by alanine: This is an incorrect option. Alanine (Ala) is a nonpolar, aliphatic amino acid, while glutamine (Gln) is a polar, uncharged amino acid. Substituting glutamine with alanine can introduce changes in the protein's structure and interactions, potentially affecting its function.

Option C - Glutamine replaced by glutamate: This is an incorrect option. Glutamate (Glu) is a negatively charged amino acid, while glutamine (Gln) is a polar, uncharged amino acid. Replacing glutamine with glutamate introduces a charge difference, which can impact the protein's structure, stability, and interactions, potentially altering its function.

Option D - Glutamine replaced by arginine: This is an incorrect option. Arginine (Arg) is a positively charged amino acid, while glutamine (Gln) is a polar, uncharged amino acid. Substituting glutamine with arginine introduces a charge difference, which can significantly impact the protein's structure, stability, and interactions, potentially leading to functional changes.

questions.text: Which of the options listed below possesses both protective and lubricating qualities?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mucin

  • Mucin is a glycoprotein that is a major component of mucus. Mucus is a slimy and viscous substance that lines various surfaces in the body, such as the respiratory tract, gastrointestinal tract, and reproductive tract.
  • Mucin plays a crucial role in protecting these surfaces by trapping pathogens, dust, and other foreign particles, preventing them from entering the body.
  • Additionally, mucin acts as a lubricant, reducing friction and facilitating the movement of materials across the epithelial surfaces. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Collagen- It provides structural support and strength to tissues and is not primarily known for its protective or lubricating properties.

Option C - Albumin- Albumin is a protein found in blood plasma and is involved in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting various substances.

Option D - Immunoglobulin- They play a crucial role in the immune response, recognizing and binding to specific antigens to neutralize or eliminate them.

questions.text: On which of the following will restriction endonucleases act?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - AAGCTT:

  • AAGCTT- This sequence is recognized by the restriction endonuclease EcoRI. EcoRI recognizes the palindromic sequence 5'-GAATTC-3' and cleaves the DNA between the G and the A bases on both strands, resulting in fragments with sticky ends. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - AAGAAG This sequence is not a recognized target for any commonly known restriction endonuclease. It does not contain a known recognition site for cleavage. Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option B - GAGAGG Similar to option A, this sequence does not contain a known recognition site for restriction endonucleases. It does not match the specific sequence required for cleavage. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option D - TACGAG This sequence does not contain a known recognition site for restriction endonucleases. It does not match any commonly recognized sequences required for cleavage. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Which medication plays a neuro-protective role in preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: MgSO4

In preterm labor, MgSO4 (Magnesium sulfate) has a neuro-protective role. It is used to prevent or minimize the risk of cerebral palsy in preterm infants by exerting neuroprotective effects on the developing brain.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Nifedipine

Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker commonly used to inhibit uterine contractions in preterm labor. However, it does not have a specific neuro-protective role.

Option C: Ritoridine

There is no drug named "Ritoridine" in the context of preterm labor. It may be a misspelling or an incorrect drug name.

Option D: Isoxsuprine

Isoxsuprine is a vasodilator that can relax uterine smooth muscle. It is sometimes used to treat preterm labor, but it does not have a specific neuro-protective role.

questions.text: When a congenital heart block is detected in a fetus, which of the following conditions would you need to assess in the mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)

  • When a congenital heart block is identified in a fetus, it is important to evaluate the mother for underlying conditions that may be associated with this condition. One of the primary conditions to consider is systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • SLE is an autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues, including the heart. Maternal autoantibodies, specifically anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB) antibodies, can cross the placenta and cause damage to the fetal heart, leading to a congenital heart block.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A (APLA syndrome): Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, which can cause blood clotting and pregnancy complications. While it can be associated with fetal loss and placental insufficiency, it is not directly related to congenital heart block.

Option B (Congenital heart defects): Congenital heart defects refer to structural abnormalities in the heart that are present at birth. While congenital heart defects can occur in infants, they are not typically associated with the development of a congenital heart block.

Option D (Hemolytic anemia): Hemolytic anemia is a condition characterized by the destruction of red blood cells, leading to anemia. While it can have various causes, it is not directly related to the development of a congenital heart block.

questions.text: All of the followings are seen in GDM except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 

Option A: Malformations.

Gestational diabetes mellitus refers to diabetes that develops during pregnancy and typically resolves after childbirth. It is characterized by high blood sugar levels that can affect both the mother and the developing fetus. However, unlike preexisting diabetes (Type 1 or Type 2), GDM is not associated with fetal malformations.

Correct Options:

Option B. Polyhydramnios: Polyhydramnios, which refers to an excessive accumulation of amniotic fluid, is a potential complication of GDM. High blood sugar levels in the mother can lead to increased production of urine by the fetus, resulting in polyhydramnios.

Option C. Fetal Macrosomia: Fetal macrosomia, which refers to a larger-than-average baby, is commonly associated with GDM. When blood sugar levels are high in the mother, the fetus receives excess glucose, leading to increased growth and potential macrosomia.

Option D. Neonatal Hypoglycemia: Neonatal hypoglycemia, or low blood sugar levels in the newborn, is a common complication of GDM. When a baby is exposed to high levels of glucose in the womb, their pancreas produces more insulin to metabolize the excess glucose. After birth, when the supply of maternal glucose is suddenly removed, the baby's blood sugar levels can drop, resulting in neonatal hypoglycemia.

questions.text: The risk of fetal varicella syndrome is highest when the mother contracts the infection during which period?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: 13 to 20 weeks.

Fetal varicella syndrome (FVS) refers to a group of birth defects that can occur in a fetus when the mother is infected with the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) during pregnancy. VZV is the virus that causes chickenpox.

The risk of FVS is highest when maternal infection occurs between the 13th and 20th weeks of pregnancy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. 6 to 10 weeks: While varicella infection during the early weeks of pregnancy can pose risks to the developing fetus, the highest risk period for FVS is considered to be between 13 and 20 weeks. The organogenesis (formation of organs) stage occurs predominantly during this time, making it a critical period for fetal development.

Option B. 8 to 12 weeks: Similar to the explanation for option A, the risk of FVS is highest between 13 and 20 weeks. The 8 to 12 week period is also important for fetal development, but the peak risk period for FVS occurs slightly later.

Option D. 20 to 28 weeks: While varicella infection during the later stages of pregnancy can still pose risks to the fetus, the risk of FVS is highest during the 13 to 20 week timeframe. By the 20th week, many of the fetal organs have already formed, reducing the risk of severe malformations caused by VZV infection.

questions.text: What is the recommended loading dose of MgSO4 for pre-eclampsia?

choices.text: 4 ml MgsO4 (50% w/v) in 16 ml NS
8 ml MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml NS
12 ml MgS04 (50% w/v) in 8 ml NS

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 8 ml of MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml of normal saline (NS).

  • In the management of pre-eclampsia, MgSO4 is commonly used for its neuroprotective effects. It is given as a loading dose followed by a maintenance dose to prevent and treat eclamptic seizures.
  • The loading dose of MgSO4 is typically administered intravenously over a specified duration. The correct loading dose is 8 ml of MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 12 ml of normal saline. This provides a total volume of 20 ml for the loading dose.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: 4 ml MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 16 ml NS: This option provides a total volume of 20 ml, but the dose of MgSO4 is half of the recommended loading dose.

Option C:.12 ml MgSO4 (50% w/v) in 8 ml NS: This option provides a total volume of 20 ml, but the dose of MgSO4 is higher than the recommended loading dose.

Option D: 10 ml MgSO4 (50% w/v): This option does not include normal saline, which is necessary for dilution. The loading dose should be administered in a diluent such as normal saline.

questions.text: What is the preferred medication for managing bacterial vaginosis in pregnant women?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Metronidazole- Metronidazole is an antibiotic that is effective against the bacteria commonly associated with bacterial vaginosis. It has been extensively studied and proven to be safe and effective in pregnancy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Fluconazole, is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections, such as yeast infections. It is not the recommended treatment for bacterial vaginosis.

Option C: Clindamycin, is another antibiotic that can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis. However, it is generally considered as an alternative to metronidazole and is reserved for cases where metronidazole cannot be used or if the infection does not respond to metronidazole.

Option D: Erythromycin is primarily used for the treatment of bacterial infections, but it is not the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: What is the purpose of using the following instrument?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: PAP smear

  • A PAP smear is a screening test used to detect abnormal cells in the cervix.
  • The above intrument is Ayre spatula used in collecting cells from the cervix

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A (VIA): Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid (VIA) is a method used to visually examine the cervix after applying acetic acid to identify any visible abnormalities or lesions.

Option B (VILI): VILI is not a recognized medical term or abbreviation, and its specific meaning is unclear in the context provided.

Option D (Colposcopy): Colposcopy is a procedure that uses a specialized instrument called a colposcope to closely examine the cervix, vagina, and vulva for any abnormal areas or lesions.

questions.text: What does this tocograph show?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. Deceleration: The tocograph shows deceleration. Decelerations in fetal heart rate patterns indicate a temporary decrease in the fetal heart rate below the baseline. It can suggest fetal distress or compromise during labor.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Acceleration: The tocograph does not show acceleration. Accelerations in fetal heart rate patterns refer to temporary increases in the fetal heart rate above the baseline. They are considered reassuring and typically indicate a healthy, responsive fetus.

Option C. Normal: The tocograph does not show a normal pattern. A normal fetal heart rate pattern would consist of a baseline heart rate within a normal range, moderate variability, and the absence of significant decelerations or accelerations.

Option D. Deceleration followed by acceleration: The tocograph does not show deceleration followed by acceleration. This pattern would involve a temporary decrease in the fetal heart rate followed by a subsequent increase

questions.text: Cause of Hydrops fetalis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Parvovirus.

Hydrops fetalis refers to a condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in the fetal compartments, such as the body cavities and tissues. It can result in severe complications and even fetal demise. There are various causes of Hydrops fetalis, but Parvovirus B19 infection is one of the known causes.

Parvovirus B19 is a common viral infection that can affect both children and adults. When a pregnant woman is infected with Parvovirus B19, it can cross the placenta and infect the developing fetus. In some cases, this can lead to the development of Hydrops fetalis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): While CMV infection is a common viral infection that can be transmitted from mother to fetus, it is not a primary cause of Hydrops fetalis. CMV infection during pregnancy can result in other complications, such as hearing loss, developmental delays, and microcephaly, but it is not specifically associated with Hydrops fetalis.

Option C. Toxoplasma: Toxoplasma infection, caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, can also be transmitted from mother to fetus. However, the presence of Toxoplasma infection is not a typical cause of Hydrops fetalis. Toxoplasmosis during pregnancy can result in other complications, such as neurological abnormalities, but Hydrops fetalis is not directly associated with Toxoplasma infection.

Option D. HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus): HIV infection, which weakens the immune system, can be transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding. However, Hydrops fetalis is not a typical consequence of HIV infection. HIV can lead to other complications in infants, such as increased susceptibility to infections, but it is not directly linked to Hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: What is the stage classification for a case of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm with lung metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C-III :

In stage III GTN, the cancer has spread to distant sites, including the lungs, but has not reached more distant organs or tissues. Lung metastasis indicates the involvement of distant sites beyond the primary tumor, which corresponds to stage III in the FIGO staging system for GTN.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A. I: Stage I GTN refers to localized disease confined to the uterus. Lung metastasis indicates spread to distant sites, indicating a more advanced stage than stage I.

Options B. II: Stage II GTN refers to disease that has spread beyond the uterus but remains within the genital structures. Lung metastasis indicates spread to distant sites beyond the genital structures, suggesting a higher stage than stage II.

Options D. IV: Stage IV GTN indicates widespread metastasis to distant organs, including the brain, liver, or other sites beyond the lungs. If the metastasis is limited to the lungs, it is not considered stage IV GTN.

questions.text: At what age in women DEXA scan is done routinely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - At 65 years:

  • Routine DEXA scan, which is used to measure bone mineral density, is typically recommended for women at the age of 65 years. This age is chosen because it is considered the threshold age for increased risk of osteoporosis and fractures in women.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B,C - routine DEXA scan is not typically recommended at this age unless there are specific risk factors present.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with numbness of both hands. He was asked to perform the test demonstrated below. What is the name of this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C  - Roos test:

  • The Roos test, also called the "Elevated Arm Stress Test is used to evaluate thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS).
  • TOS is a condition characterized by the compression or irritation of the neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet, which can lead to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and weakness in the upper extremities.
  • During the Roos test, the patient is asked to actively elevate both arms to 90 degrees, flex the elbows to 90 degrees, and open and close their hands for approximately three minutes. If the patient experiences symptoms, such as numbness, tingling, or the inability to maintain the position due to pain or weakness, it may indicate a positive Roos test, suggesting the presence of TOS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Adson's Test:

  • Adson's test is another test used to evaluate TOS. It involves checking the radial pulse while the patient rotates their head and extends their neck. This test is not demonstrated in the scenario.

Option B - Pemberton Test:

  • The Pemberton test is used to assess for thoracic outlet syndrome caused by the compression of structures between the clavicle and the first rib. It involves raising both arms above the head (180 degrees anterior flexion at the shoulder) while monitoring for symptoms. Unlike the Roos test, it does not involve pumping the fists.

 

Option D - Wright Test:

  • The Wright test, also known as the Hyperabduction Test, is a clinical examination used to diagnose thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). TOS is a condition characterized by compression of the neurovascular bundle (nerves, arteries, and veins) as it passes through the thoracic outlet. The Wright test specifically assesses for compression of the subclavian artery and the brachial plexus by the pectoralis minor muscle.

questions.text: A child presents with difficulty in walking. On biopsy of the hip, some cells with grooved nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm are present. Which investigation would you order next?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - CD1a Marker:

  • The presence of cells with grooved nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm on hip biopsy suggests the possibility of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH), also known as histiocytosis X. CD1a marker is a specific immuno histochemical stain used to identify Langerhans cells, which are characteristic cells seen in LCH. Therefore, ordering the CD1a marker test would be the appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While an MRI scan can provide detailed images of the hip joint and surrounding structures, it is not specific for diagnosing Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It may be useful in evaluating the extent of involvement or complications related to LCH, but it would not provide a definitive diagnosis.

Option B - Serum Calcium: Serum calcium levels may be elevated in some cases of Langerhans cell histiocytosis, but it is not a specific diagnostic test for this condition. Serum calcium alone cannot confirm or exclude the diagnosis of LCH.

Option C - Serum PTH (Parathyroid Hormone): Serum PTH levels are not directly related to the diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. This test is typically used in the evaluation of parathyroid gland function and calcium regulation and is not specific to LCH.

questions.text: A fracture of the distal femur is stabilized as shown in the image using:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rail Fixator:

  • Rail fixator, also known as a dynamic external fixator, is a type of external fixation device used for stabilizing and aligning fractured bones. It consists of metal rods or pins that are inserted into the bone on either side of the fracture site. These rods are connected by an external frame, which provides stability and allows for controlled movement and weight-bearing during the healing process.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Illizarov Fixator: The Ilizarov fixator is a different type of external fixation device that uses rings and wires to stabilize fractures and perform limb lengthening procedures.

Option C - K Wire Binding: K-wires, or Kirschner wires, are used for temporary fixation of fractures, but they are not the primary choice for stabilizing a distal femur fracture.

Option D - Interlocking Nail: Interlocking nails, also known as intramedullary nails, are commonly used for stabilizing long bone fractures, but they are primarily used for fractures that occur within the medullary canal, not for distal femur fractures.

questions.text: Paradoxical undressing is seen in :
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: C

  • Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon that can occur in cases of severe hypothermia.
  • When a person is experiencing extreme cold and their core body temperature drops significantly, paradoxical undressing refers to the behaviour of the individual inexplicably removing their clothing, often resulting in being found partially or completely naked.
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction caused by cold temperatures may also contribute to discomfort, leading to clothing removal.

Incorrect option: 

Option A. Heart stress: Heart stress, also known as cardiac stress or cardiac strain, refers to excessive strain or demand placed on the heart. It is not associated with paradoxical undressing.

Option B. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is a paraphilic disorder characterized by deriving sexual pleasure from observing others without their consent. It is unrelated to paradoxical undressing.

Option D. LSD overdose: LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogenic drug, and an overdose of LSD can lead to various physiological and psychological effects. However, paradoxical undressing is not a recognized symptom or consequence of LSD overdose.

questions.text: An 11 year old girl was found to be quiet and shy in her classroom with intermittent crying, for the past few days. It was discovered that her uncle was touching her genitals inappropriately. The duty of the principal is to report this to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Police:

  • Reporting the incident to the police is crucial because they have the authority and responsibility to investigate cases of child abuse, including inappropriate touching or sexual abuse.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Magistrate: The police are the appropriate authority to handle the initial investigation and take immediate action to protect the child.

Option C - Child welfare committee: Child welfare committees play a crucial role in child protection, but the immediate action in cases of abuse is to report to the police.

Option D - Parents: While it is important to inform the parents or guardians of the child about the incident, the primary responsibility of the principal in such cases is to report to the police.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for:

choices.text: Nibbling the ends of the bones

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Holding the bone and plate: 

  • A bone holding forceps, as shown in the image, is used for holding the bone and plate during orthopedic procedures. It provides a firm grip on the bone and allows for precise manipulation and stabilization. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nibbling the ends of the bones: This refers to instruments like bone nibblers, which are used for removing small bone fragments or trimming bone edges.

Option C - Controlled traction of fracture segments: Instruments like fracture hooks or reduction forceps are used for applying controlled traction to align and stabilize fracture segments.

Option D - Cutting the K-wire: Instruments like wire cutters or wire scissors are specifically designed for cutting K-wires, which are used for fixation in orthopedic procedures.

questions.text: The postmortem change seen in the image below corresponds to which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Ans: A

  • Marbling: Marbling refers to the mottled appearance of blood vessels seen on the surface of the skin or internal organs due to the formation of blood clots after death. This change occurs as a result of the breakdown of blood cells and the settling of blood components. Marbling is commonly observed in the early stages of decomposition.

Incorrect option: 

Option B. Algor mortis: Algor mortis refers to the cooling of the body after death. It is the gradual loss of body heat until the body reaches the ambient temperature. It is not directly associated with any visual changes on the body.

Option C. Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of the muscles after death due to the coagulation of muscle proteins. It is a temporary condition that usually starts within a few hours after death and resolves after 24 to 48 hours.

Option D. Post mortem lividity: Post mortem lividity, also known as livor mortis, is the pooling or settling of blood in the dependent parts of the body after death. It results in a purplish or bluish discoloration of the skin in the lower areas due to gravity.

questions.text: What is the most likely reason for an 8-month-old baby being brought to the hospital with issues of inadequate feeding and unusual spasms in the lower limb, along with symptoms of fever, bulging fontanelle, and lethargy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Meningitis:

  • The patient’s presentation with fever, bulging fontanelle, lethargy, inadequate feeding and unusual spasms in the lower limb are suggestive of meningitis
  • In infants and young children, the symptoms of meningitis can be non-specific but may include poor feeding, irritability, abnormal movements, fever, and changes in consciousness.
  • The fontanelle, a soft spot on the baby's skull, may appear bulging due to increased intracranial pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A 28 year old man presented with dry mouth, urinary retention, and constipation after consuming an unknown substance. On examination, his PR 110 bpm, and his pupils were dilated. What did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Belladona: 

  • Belladonna, also known as deadly nightshade, contains tropane alkaloids such as atropine and scopolamine. These substances are known to cause anticholinergic effects, which include dry mouth, urinary retention, constipation, increased heart rate (tachycardia), and dilated pupils (mydriasis).

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Heroin: Heroin is an opioid drug that acts on opioid receptors in the central nervous system. While opioids like heroin can cause respiratory depression, they typically do not produce significant anticholinergic effects. Common effects of heroin use include euphoria, drowsiness, pinpoint pupils (miosis), respiratory depression, and constipation. Dry mouth, urinary retention, and dilated pupils are not typical symptoms associated with heroin use.

Option B - Morphine: Morphine is another opioid drug with similar effects to heroin. Like heroin, morphine primarily acts on opioid receptors and can cause respiratory depression and constipation. However, it does not typically produce pronounced anticholinergic effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and dilated pupils.

Option C - Malathion: Malathion is an organophosphate insecticide. Ingestion of malathion can lead to symptoms such as excessive salivation, sweating, and constricted pupils (miosis), rather than the anticholinergic effects described in the case.

questions.text: What specific actions are taken for the management of a 3-week-old neonate with ambiguous genitalia, a sodium level of 127, a potassium level of 6 meq, and a blood pressure of 50/22 mm Hg, in addition to administering intravenous fluids?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hydrocortisone:

  • The patient’s presentation with ambiguous genitalia, a low serum sodium level, a high serum potassium level, and a low BP is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
  • CAH is a group of autosomal recessive disorders characterized by impaired cortisol synthesis, leading to an accumulation of precursors and subsequent adrenal gland hyperplasia.
  • The most common enzyme deficiency causing CAH is 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • In a neonate with CAH, the low cortisol levels lead to an overproduction of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which stimulates the adrenal glands to produce excess androgens.
  • This can result in ambiguous genitalia in females and precocious pseudopuberty in males.
  • The specific management in this case involves administration of hydrocortisone, a glucocorticoid, to replace the deficient cortisol and suppress the excessive ACTH production.
  • Hydrocortisone helps to normalize electrolyte imbalances, such as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, and improve blood pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text:
Which option is correct regarding techniques of organ removal during autopsy :

A. Rockitansky – In situ

B. Virchow – en masse

C. Ghon’s – en block

D. Letulle – One by one

choices.text: A, B and C are correct
B and D, A are correct
A, B, C and D are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A and C:

  • Rockitansky – In situ: This technique refers to the removal of organs one by one while keeping them in their original position within the body. It allows for a more detailed examination and dissection of each organ individually. eg. in cases of HIV, Hep B etc.
  • Ghon's – en block: Ghon's technique involves the removal of multiple organs as a single unit or block.
  • This technique is commonly used in organ transplantation procedures to preserve the integrity of the organs and minimize ischemic time.
  • Organs removed as organ blocks and subsequently dissected

Incorrect Option:

Option B - A, B, and C are correct:

  • Rockitansky – In situ: Explained above.
  • B is incorrect – Virchows – One by One: Technique, also known as the "one by one" technique, is a method used in autopsies. hence does not match as written above.
  • Ghon's – en block: Explained above.

Option C - B and D, A are correct:

  • Virchows – One by one: Technique, also known as the "one by one" technique, is a method used in autopsies. It involves the sequential removal of organs for examination and analysis, allowing for a systematic and thorough assessment of each organ individually.
  • Letulle method, also known as “en masse”. In this method, the entire organ block is removed as one. hence does not match as written above.

Option D - A, B, C and D are correct:

  • B and D both are incorrect

questions.text: The procedure displayed below is:
questions.solution:
Correct option C: Nasogastric tube insertion:

  • Nasogastric tube insertion involves the placement of a tube through the nose into the stomach.
  • This procedure is commonly performed to administer medications, give feedings, or decompress the stomach.
  • It is often used when a patient is unable to take food or medication orally or when there is a need to remove gastric contents.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Intubation: Intubation refers to the placement of an endotracheal tube into the trachea to establish a secure airway for mechanical ventilation.

Option B: Orogastric tube insertion: Orogastric tube insertion involves the placement of a tube through the mouth into the stomach.

Option D: Oropharyngeal airway insertion:

  • Oropharyngeal airway insertion involves the placement of a curved device into the mouth to maintain an open airway and facilitate ventilation.
  • It is commonly used during resuscitation efforts or in unconscious patients.

questions.text: Which of the following indicates a "infant at risk"?

choices.text: Mother who has not taken folic acid during pregnancy
Infant with history of premature birth <32 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct option C: Infant with history of premature birth <32 weeks:

  • An "infant at risk" refers to a newborn baby who has certain factors or conditions that increase their vulnerability or likelihood of experiencing adverse health outcomes.
  • In this case, a history of premature birth before 32 weeks gestation indicates that the infant was born significantly earlier than the normal gestational period.
  • Premature infants often require specialized medical care and are at higher risk for various complications due to their underdeveloped organs and physiological systems.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Working mother:

  • Being a working mother does not necessarily indicate that the infant is at risk.
  • Many mothers successfully balance work and childcare responsibilities without impacting the baby's health.

Option B: Mother who has not taken folic acid during pregnancy: While folic acid supplementation is important for fetal development and reducing the risk of certain birth defects, the absence of folic acid intake alone does not categorize the infant as being at risk.

Option D: Pre-eclampsia:

  • Pre-eclampsia is a maternal condition characterized by high blood pressure and organ damage during pregnancy.
  • While it can have implications for the mother's health, it does not directly classify the infant as being at risk.
  • However, pre-eclampsia may lead to preterm birth, which would then increase the infant's risk due to prematurity.

questions.text: What could be the likely diagnosis for an 8-year-old boy who has sensorineural hearing loss, eye defects, and presents with hematuria in the outpatient department, considering that his renal biopsy showed no abnormalities, and his maternal uncle has end-stage chronic kidney disease (CKD) and is currently undergoing dialysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Alport Syndrome:

  • The patient’s presentation with sensorineural hearing loss, eye defects, hematuria, and a history of maternal uncle with end-stage chronic kidney disease (CKD) undergoing dialysis is suggestive of Alport syndrome.
  • Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities.
  • It is caused by mutations in genes encoding type IV collagen, which is an important component of the basement membrane in the kidney, inner ear, and eyes.
  • The classic triad of symptoms includes hematuria, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.
  • In some cases, renal biopsy may appear normal on light microscopy, but electron microscopy or immunohistochemistry may reveal characteristic findings.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Goodpasture syndrome:

  • Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antibodies directed against the basement membrane of the kidneys and lungs.
  • It typically presents with pulmonary and renal involvement, including pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis.

Option C: IgA nephropathy:

  • IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder characterized by the deposition of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in the glomeruli.
  • It commonly presents with episodes of hematuria and can progress to chronic kidney disease.

Option D: PSGN:

  • PSGN is a type of glomerulonephritis that occurs after an infection with certain strains of streptococcus bacteria.
  • It is characterized by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to inflammation and kidney damage.

questions.text: Clostridium difficile associated diarrhea occurs maximally due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lincosamides: 

  • Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) occurs maximally due to the use of lincosamides. Lincosamides are a class of antibiotics that includes drugs like clindamycin. These antibiotics have been strongly associated with the development of CDAD. They disrupt the normal gut microbiota, allowing Clostridium difficile, a bacteria that can cause diarrhea, to overgrow and produce toxins.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tetracyclines: While tetracyclines can also be associated with the development of CDAD, lincosamides have a higher association.

Option C - Carbapenems: Carbapenems, a broad-spectrum antibiotic class, are not typically associated with an increased risk of CDAD. However, they can disrupt the normal gut microbiota and lead to other gastrointestinal side effects.

Option D - Macrolides: Macrolides, such as erythromycin or azithromycin, have a lower risk of causing CDAD compared to lincosamides. They are not commonly associated with CDAD, although they can have other gastrointestinal side effects.

questions.text:
Evaluate the following statements with respect to inter – trochanteric fracture, and opt for the correct ones  :


	More common in males than females
	One – year mortality rate is about 20 to 30%
	It is more commonly associated with non – union than fracture neck of femur
	One year mortality rate can be reduced by operating within 48 hours
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 2 and 4 are correct: 

Statement 2: One-year mortality rate is about 20 to 30% - This statement is correct. The one-year mortality rate for inter-trochanteric fractures can range from 20 to 30%, depending on various factors such as the patient's age, overall health, and the presence of comorbidities.

Statement 4: One-year mortality rate can be reduced by operating within 48 hours - This statement is correct. Early surgical intervention within 48 hours of the fracture has been shown to reduce the risk of complications and improve outcomes, including the mortality rate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1 and 3 are correct:

  • Statement 1: More common in males than females - This statement is incorrect. Inter-trochanteric fractures do not show a significant gender predilection and can occur in both males and females.
  • Statement 3: It is more commonly associated with non-union than fracture neck of femur - This statement is incorrect. Inter-trochanteric fractures generally have a lower risk of non-union compared to fractures of the neck of the femur.

Option B - 1, 2, 3 are correct:

  • Statement 2: One-year mortality rate is about 20 to 30% - This statement is incorrect. The one-year mortality rate for inter-trochanteric fractures is typically lower than 20-30%.

Option D - 1, 2, 3, 4 are correct:

  • The correct option is C: 2 and 4 are correct. The statements regarding the one-year mortality rate and the ability to reduce mortality by operating within 48 hours are accurate, while the statements about the gender distribution and association with non-union are incorrect.

questions.text: A 53 year old man is found to have stage 2 hypertension without any co morbidities. Which drug will you start ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chlorthalidone: 

  • In a 53-year-old man with stage 2 hypertension and no co-morbidities, the preferred initial medication would be a thiazide-like diuretic. Chlorthalidone , which belongs to the thiazide class of diuretics, is an appropriate choice.

  • Thiazide diuretics, such as, Chlorthalidone are considered first-line agents for treating hypertension due to their proven efficacy and safety profile. They help lower blood pressure by promoting diuresis (increased urine production) and reducing fluid volume in the body. This results in a decrease in systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic, which is more potent than thiazide diuretics. They are not usually the first-line choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

Option C - Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and is often used as an adjunct therapy in cases where additional blood pressure control is needed. It is not typically used as monotherapy for initial treatment of hypertension.

Option D - Triamterene: Triamterene is another potassium-sparing diuretic commonly used in combination with other diuretics to reduce potassium loss. It is not typically used as monotherapy for initial treatment of hypertension.

questions.text: LMWH is given by which route?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Subcutaneous:

  • LMWH (Low Molecular Weight Heparin) is typically administered via the subcutaneous route. Subcutaneous administration involves injecting the medication into the fatty tissue layer just beneath the skin. This route allows for slow and sustained absorption of the medication into the bloodstream. LMWH is specifically formulated for subcutaneous use and is available in pre-filled syringes or cartridges.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intravenous (IV): LMWH is not typically administered intravenously. Regular heparin can be given intravenously.

Option C - Intramuscular (IM): LMWH is not administered intramuscularly as it can cause pain, hematoma formation, and unpredictable absorption.

Option D - Intradermal (ID): LMWH is not administered intradermally as it is not intended for local effects and may not be well absorbed through the skin.

questions.text:
Match the following images with their respective diagnosis.

.

A. Osteogenesis imperfecta

B. Klippel – Feil syndrome

C. Neurofibromatosis

D. Marfan’s syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-D, 2-B, 3-C; 4-A:

1. Image matches with Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissues, resulting in various skeletal abnormalities and cardiovascular problems. The image shown likely represents a person with Marfan's syndrome.

  • Marfan's syndrome primarily affects the cardiovascular system, eyes, and skeletal system.
  • People with Marfan's syndrome tend to have tall stature, long limbs, flexible joints, and abnormalities of the heart valves and blood vessels.
  • Eye problems such as nearsightedness and lens dislocation are also common.
  • Marfan's syndrome is caused by mutations in the gene that produces fibrillin, an essential protein for connective tissue strength.

2. Image matches with Klippel-Feil syndrome: Klippel-Feil syndrome is a congenital condition characterized by the fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae. This can lead to a short neck and limited range of motion. The image likely shows the characteristic neck abnormalities associated with Klippel-Feil syndrome.

3. Image matches with Neurofibromatosis: Neurofibromatosis is a genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. The image may depict a person with neurofibromatosis, showcasing the presence of neurofibromas or other characteristic skin manifestations associated with the condition.

  • There are two main types: NF1 and NF2. NF1 is characterized by the growth of non-cancerous tumors on or under the skin, pigment changes, and skeletal abnormalities. NF2 is less common and primarily involves the growth of tumors on the nerves responsible for hearing and balance. NF can have varying symptoms and severity, ranging from mild to severe.

4. Image matches with Osteogenesis imperfecta: Osteogenesis imperfecta, also known as brittle bone disease, is a genetic disorder that results in fragile bones that are prone to fractures. The image does not correspond to this condition, as it does not show any specific bone abnormalities.

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder characterized by fragile bones that are prone to fractures. It is commonly known as "brittle bone disease." People with OI may have weak bones, brittle teeth, hearing loss, and other connective tissue-related symptoms. It is caused by mutations in genes responsible for producing collagen, the major protein in bone structure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1-A, 2-B, 3-C; 4-D: The image does not match with Osteogenesis imperfecta, Klippel-Feil syndrome, or Neurofibromatosis, and therefore, it cannot correspond to Marfan's syndrome.

Option B - 1-D, 2-C, 3-B; 4-A: The image does not match with Marfan's syndrome, Neurofibromatosis, or Klippel-Feil syndrome, and therefore, it cannot correspond to Osteogenesis imperfecta.

Option C - 1-D, 2-C, 3-A; 4-B: The image does not match with Marfan's syndrome, Neurofibromatosis, or Osteogenesis imperfecta, and therefore, it cannot correspond to Klippel-Feil syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, and salivation. His pulse rate is 55/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 50U/mL. Which of the following can be used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atropine:

  • The patient's symptoms and clinical presentation are consistent with cholinergic toxicity or poisoning, which is caused by excessive stimulation of the cholinergic system. Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that can be used as an antidote in cases of cholinergic toxicity.
  • Atropine works by blocking the effects of acetylcholine, the neurotransmitter responsible for cholinergic stimulation. By inhibiting acetylcholine, atropine helps counteract the excessive cholinergic activity and relieve symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neostigmine: Neostigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that increases cholinergic activity. It would exacerbate the symptoms in a patient with cholinergic toxicity and is not appropriate for treatment.

Option C - Epinephrine: Epinephrine is a sympathomimetic agent that stimulates adrenergic receptors. It would not be effective in treating cholinergic toxicity.

Option D - Benztropine: Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication used primarily for the treatment of Parkinson's disease and drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms. While it has anticholinergic properties, it is not commonly used for the treatment of acute cholinergic toxicity.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			
				Madelung deformity
				Haglund deformity
				Button hole deformity
				Gun stock deformity
			
			
			
			A. Cubitus varus

			B. Cubitus valgus

			C. Rheumatoid arthritis

			D. Volar ulnar deviation

			E. Calcaneum enlargement on back of heel
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-D, 2-E, 3-C; 4-A:

  1. Madelung deformity: Matched with D. Volar ulnar deviation. Madelung deformity is a wrist deformity characterized by a volar (palmar) and ulnar deviation of the wrist joint. This results in a noticeable prominence of the ulna and a tilted wrist.
  2. Haglund deformity: Matched with E. Calcaneum enlargement on the back of the heel. Haglund deformity is a condition where there is a bony enlargement at the back of the heel bone (calcaneus), causing pain and discomfort.
  3. Buttonhole deformity: Matched with C. Rheumatoid arthritis. Buttonhole deformity is a finger deformity commonly seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. It involves flexion contracture of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint with hyperextension of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint, resembling a buttonhole.
  4. Gunstock deformity: Matched with A. Cubitus varus. Gunstock deformity refers to the angular deformity of the elbow joint where the forearm deviates inward towards the midline of the body. This results in a varus alignment of the elbow joint.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1-E, 2-D, 3-C; 4-A: This option incorrectly matches Madelung deformity with E instead of D.

Option C - 1-D, 2-E, 3-A; 4-B: This option incorrectly matches Madelung deformity with D instead of A, and matches Haglund deformity with E instead of D.

Option D - 1-D, 2-E, 3-B; 4-A: This option incorrectly matches Buttonhole deformity with B instead of C.

questions.text:
Which of the following are toxins?


	Atropine
	Colchicine
	Curare
	Arsenic
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1, 2, 3 are correct:

  • 1, 2 and 3 are correct. Atropine, colchicine, and curare are all toxins.

  • Atropine, colchicine, and curare are substances that possess toxic properties.

  • Atropine is a naturally occurring substance found in certain plants, colchicine is a toxic alkaloid found in the autumn crocus plant, and curare refers to a group of natural toxins obtained from South American plants. Arsenic, on the other hand, is not classified as a toxin, but rather as a toxic element.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - All are correct: This option is incorrect because arsenic is not considered a toxin.

Option C -1, 3 are correct: This option is incorrect because it fails to include colchicine (option 2), which is indeed a toxin.

Option D - 3, 4 are correct: This option is incorrect because it includes arsenic (option 4), which is not a toxin

questions.text:
Please arrange the following clauses of IPC 320 in sequential order.


	Destruction or permanent impairing of the power of any member or joint
	Permanent disfiguration of the head or face
	Emasculation
