Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about exhumation?

choices.text: The executive magistrate can order for exhumation
Postmortem can be done on exhumated body

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A - The executive magistrate can order for exhumation

  • Exhumation - It is digging out of an already buried body legally from the grave
  • exhumation is done only when there is written order from executive magistrate.
  • The body can be exhumated by any government doctor.

Incorrect Option: 

Option B Police can order for exhumation : This statement is incorrect

Option C Postmortem can be done on exhumated body : Autopsies can be performed on exhumated bodies

Option D CrPC 174 is related to exhumation: CrPC 176 is related to exhumation

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trimetazidine:

  • Trimetazidine is not commonly used in the management of heart failure. It is primarily used in the treatment of angina pectoris and ischemic heart disease. Trimetazidine acts by improving myocardial glucose utilization and reducing fatty acid oxidation, which helps in preserving cardiac energy metabolism. However, it does not have direct effects on heart failure pathophysiology, such as reducing preload or afterload, improving cardiac contractility, or inhibiting neurohormonal activation, which are important therapeutic targets in heart failure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sacubitril: Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor used in the management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). It is combined with the angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) valsartan to form sacubitril/valsartan, which has been shown to reduce cardiovascular mortality and hospitalizations in HFrEF patients.

Option C - Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker commonly used in the treatment of heart failure. It helps in reducing heart rate, blood pressure, and cardiac workload, thereby improving symptoms and outcomes in heart failure patients.

Option D - Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a recombinant form of human B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) used in acute decompensated heart failure. It has vasodilatory and diuretic effects, leading to decreased preload and afterload, improved cardiac output, and relief of symptoms in acute heart failure episodes. However, its long-term use in chronic heart failure is limited.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is non-pulsatile dosing of GnRH agonist not used?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Male infertility:

  • Non-pulsatile dosing of GnRH agonist is not used in male infertility because pulsatile release of GnRH is necessary to stimulate the secretion of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), which are essential for spermatogenesis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Endometriosis: Non-pulsatile dosing of GnRH agonist is commonly used in endometriosis to suppress the production of estrogen and induce a hypoestrogenic state, which helps in reducing the symptoms and progression of the disease.

Option C - Precocious puberty: Non-pulsatile dosing of GnRH agonist is used in precocious puberty to suppress the production of gonadotropins, thereby delaying the onset of puberty and preventing early maturation of secondary sexual characteristics.

Option D - Prostate cancer: Non-pulsatile dosing of GnRH agonist is commonly used in prostate cancer to achieve and maintain medical castration by suppressing the production of gonadotropins and reducing testosterone levels, which helps in the treatment of hormone-sensitive prostate cancer.

questions.text: Prucalopride is a ___________:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 5HT4 agonist:

  • Prucalopride is a 5HT4 agonist. It selectively activates the 5HT4 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract. By binding to and stimulating these receptors, prucalopride promotes increased gut motility and enhances the movement of stool. This helps to alleviate chronic constipation and improve bowel function.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 5HT2a agonist: Prucalopride does not primarily target the 5HT2a receptors. Activation of the 5HT2a receptors is associated with various effects, including vasoconstriction, hallucinations, and changes in mood and cognition. Prucalopride's mechanism of action is primarily through 5HT4 receptor activation.

Option B - 5HT2b agonist: Prucalopride does not primarily target the 5HT2b receptors. Activation of the 5HT2b receptors is associated with effects such as cardiac valve fibrosis. Prucalopride's therapeutic action is not mediated through 5HT2b receptor activation.

Option C - 5HT4 antagonist: Prucalopride is a 5HT4 agonist, not an antagonist. As mentioned earlier, prucalopride stimulates the 5HT4 receptors, leading to enhanced gastrointestinal motility and improved bowel function.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about anterior shoulder dislocation except :

choices.text: Recurrence rate is maximum if the patients age less than 20 years
Axillary nerve is most commonly injured
CT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion
Anterior shoulder dislocation is most common typeof shoulder dislocation,

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion:

  • CCT scan is preferred for knowing the bony lesion: This statement is incorrect.
  • While CT scans can provide detailed information about bony lesions in the shoulder, they are not typically the first-line imaging modality used for diagnosing anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • The primary method for diagnosing shoulder dislocation is a combination of clinical evaluation, physical examination, and X-ray imaging.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Recurrent rate is maximum if the patients age less than 20 years: This statement is correct. Anterior shoulder dislocation has a higher recurrence rate in patients younger than 20 years of age. This is due to the increased laxity of the joint structures and the higher likelihood of engaging in activities that can cause shoulder instability.

Option B - Axillary nerve is most commonly injured: This statement is correct. The axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle and the skin over the shoulder, is commonly injured in anterior shoulder dislocations. The nerve can be stretched, compressed, or damaged during the dislocation, leading to temporary or permanent weakness or sensory loss.

Option D - Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common type of shoulder dislocation: This statement is correct. Anterior shoulder dislocation is indeed the most common type of shoulder dislocation, accounting for the majority of all shoulder dislocations.

questions.text: Which is not used in treatment in Wilson’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Calcium citrate:

  • Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the abnormal accumulation of copper in various organs, primarily the liver and brain. The mainstay of treatment for Wilson's disease involves the use of medications that help reduce copper levels in the body. These medications include:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Zinc: Zinc acts by blocking the absorption of copper from the diet and promotes the excretion of copper in the stool. It is commonly used as a first-line therapy for Wilson's disease.

Option B - Penicillamine: Penicillamine is a chelating agent that binds to copper and facilitates its removal from the body through urine. It is also used in the treatment of Wilson's disease, especially in patients who cannot tolerate or do not respond to zinc therapy.

Option D - Trientine: Trientine is another chelating agent used in the treatment of Wilson's disease. It works similarly to penicillamine by binding to copper and promoting its elimination from the body.

questions.text: Which of the following statement about septic arthritis is true

choices.text: Staph aureus is most common organism in adults
Incision and drainage done after culture of aspirate and antibiotic for 24 hours
Kocher’s criteria is used to differentiate from transient synovitis
Widening of joint space is seen

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Incision and drainage done after culture of aspirate and antibiotic for 24 hours:

  • True - Incision and drainage should be performed after obtaining a culture of the joint aspirate and initiating antibiotic therapy for at least 24 hours. This statement is correct as it is essential to identify the causative organism and initiate appropriate antibiotic treatment before performing surgical drainage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Staph aureus is most common organism in adults:

  •  False - Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children. This statement is incorrect as Staphylococcus aureus is a common causative organism in septic arthritis, especially in children.

Option C - Kocher’s criteria is used to differentiate from transient synovitis:

  • False - Kocher's criteria are not used to differentiate septic arthritis from transient synovitis. This statement is incorrect. Kocher's criteria are used to assess the likelihood of septic arthritis in children with an acutely painful hip, based on factors such as fever, inability to bear weight, elevated white blood cell count, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. It helps in determining the need for further diagnostic evaluation and treatment.

Option D - Widening of joint space is seen:

  • False - Widening of the joint space is not typically seen in septic arthritis. This statement is incorrect. In septic arthritis, joint space narrowing is more commonly observed due to the accumulation of inflammatory fluid and destruction of articular structures.

questions.text: What dose of epinephrine is used anaphylactic shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1:1000 I.M. - 0.5 ml:

  • In the management of anaphylactic shock, epinephrine is the drug of choice as it helps reverse the severe allergic reaction and relieve symptoms. The recommended dose of epinephrine for anaphylactic shock is 1:1000 concentration, which means 1 mg of epinephrine in 1 mL of solution. It is administered intramuscularly (I.M.) in the mid-anterolateral aspect of the thigh.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 1:10000 I.V. - 10 mL: Represents a more diluted concentration and a higher volume, which is not the standard dose for anaphylactic shock.

Option C - 1:1000 I.M. - 1 mL: Represents a higher volume of epinephrine than the recommended dose.

Option D - 1:1000 I.V. - 0.5 mL: Represents the correct concentration but the incorrect route of administration. Intravenous (I.V.) administration of epinephrine is reserved for severe cases and should be administered by healthcare professionals.

questions.text:
Assertion: Proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis

Reason : Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is correct not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Assertion is false, but the reason is true
Both assertion is and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Both the assertion and the reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

  •  The proximal pole of the scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. This means that the blood supply to the proximal pole is compromised, leading to tissue death.
  •  The reason given is that the blood supply to the scaphoid bone is retrograde, meaning it flows from the distal end (near the wrist) towards the proximal end (closer to the forearm). This retrograde blood supply makes the proximal pole more vulnerable to avascular necrosis as it receives blood last.
  • The reason provided in the statement correctly explains why the proximal pole of the scaphoid is more prone to avascular necrosis. The retrograde blood supply pattern makes this region of the bone more susceptible to ischemia and subsequent necrosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - This option suggests that both the assertion and the reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: However, the reason is indeed the correct explanation for the assertion.

Option C - This option states that the assertion is true, but the reason is false: However, the reason is true and provides a valid explanation for the assertion.

Option D - This option suggests that the assertion is false, but the reason is true: However, the assertion is indeed true, as supported by the high incidence of avascular necrosis in the proximal pole of the scaphoid.

Option E - This option states that both the assertion and the reason are false: However, both the assertion and the reason are true and supported by clinical evidence.

questions.text:
Chlorpromazine acts on which of the following receptor?

1) D2 and 5-HT2 receptor

2) GABA and beta - adrenergic receptor

3) Muscarinic M1 and alpha - adrenergic receptors

4) H1 receptors
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1, 3 and 4 are correct

Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that acts on multiple receptors in the body. Let's examine each option:

  • (1) D2 and 5-HT2 receptor: Chlorpromazine primarily acts as an antagonist at the D2 dopamine receptors and the 5-HT2 serotonin receptors. By blocking these receptors, chlorpromazine helps to reduce the symptoms of psychosis and has antipsychotic effects.

  • (3) Muscarinic M1 and alpha-adrenergic receptors: Chlorpromazine also exhibits antagonistic effects at the muscarinic M1 receptors and the alpha-adrenergic receptors. Antagonism at muscarinic receptors can lead to side effects such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and constipation. Antagonism at alpha-adrenergic receptors can result in symptoms like orthostatic hypotension (low blood pressure when standing up).

  • (4) H1 receptors: Chlorpromazine also acts as an antagonist at the H1 histamine receptors. Blockade of H1 receptors contributes to the sedative effects of chlorpromazine.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Only 2 is correct: Chlorpromazine does not primarily act on GABA and beta-adrenergic receptors. While it does have some interaction with these receptors, it is not the primary mechanism of action.

Option C - 1 and 2 are correct: While option 1 (D2 and 5-HT2 receptor) is correct, option 2 (GABA and beta-adrenergic receptor) is not accurate. Chlorpromazine's main actions are not related to GABA or beta-adrenergic receptors.

Option D - All are correct: While options 1 and 4 are correct, option 3 (Muscarinic M1 and alpha-adrenergic receptors) is inaccurate. Chlorpromazine does act on these receptors, but it is not the primary focus of its pharmacological effects.

questions.text:
Assertion: Larger doses of acyclovir are recommended for treatment of genital herpes in HIV positive patients

Reason: Frequent recurrences of genital herpes is seen in HIV patients

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and reason is correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true and reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Assertion is false, but the reason is true
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option A.

  • Assertion: Larger doses of acyclovir are recommended for the treatment of genital herpes in HIV-positive patients. This assertion is true because HIV-positive patients tend to experience more frequent recurrences of genital herpes.
  • Reason: Frequent recurrences of genital herpes are seen in HIV patients. This reason is also true and provides a valid explanation for the assertion. The compromised immune system in HIV-positive individuals can lead to more frequent reactivation of the herpes virus, requiring higher doses of acyclovir or other antiviral medications to effectively manage the infection.
  • Since both the assertion and reason are true and the reason correctly explains the assertion, option A is the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is incorrect because the reason provided is indeed the correct explanation for the assertion.

Option C. Assertion is true, but the reason is false: This option is incorrect because both the assertion and reason are true.

Option D. Assertion is false, but the reason is true: This option is incorrect because the assertion is true, as HIV-positive patients do require larger doses of acyclovir for genital herpes treatment.

Option E. Both assertion and reason are false: This option is incorrect because both the assertion and reason are true.

questions.text: Aspirin and phenobarbitone are acidic drugs whereas diazepam is a basic drug, mark the false statement about these drugs:

choices.text: Aspirin is present in mainly non – ionized form in stomach, hence can be easily absorbed
Diazepam is mostly absorbed from intestine
Phenobarbitone can be absorbed from the stomach.
Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs like diarrhea will increase the drug absorption in the small intestine

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs like diarrhoea will increase the drug absorption in the small intestine.:

  • The statement that diseases decreasing the transit time of drugs like diarrhoea will increase drug absorption in the small intestine is incorrect. Diarrhea, which is characterized by increased intestinal motility and decreased transit time, can actually decrease drug absorption as the drug has less time to be absorbed in the intestine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aspirin is present in mainly non-ionized form in the stomach, which allows it to be easily absorbed: Non-ionized forms of drugs are generally more lipid-soluble and can readily cross biological membranes.

Option B - Diazepam is mostly absorbed from the intestine: Diazepam is a basic drug and is well-absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, primarily in the small intestine.

Option C - Phenobarbital can be absorbed from the stomach. Phenobarbital is an acidic drug. Therefore, its absorption is primarily facilitated in the stomach and upper small intestine, where the pH is relatively lower.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in relation to antiviral medications:

choices.text: Imiquimod used in treatment of condyloma acuminata
Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C
Oseltamivir is used for swine flu

questions.solution:
Correct Option A.

Ombitasvir is not involved in the prevention of HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) protein synthesis. Ombitasvir is actually a direct-acting antiviral agent that is part of a combination therapy used for the treatment of chronic hepatitis C infection. It specifically targets the HCV NS5A protein, which is involved in viral replication and assembly.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Imiquimod used in the treatment of condyloma acuminata: Imiquimod is an immune response modifier that is used topically in the treatment of certain viral infections, including genital warts (condyloma acuminata). It stimulates the body's immune system to produce interferon and other cytokines, which help in the elimination of the viral infection.

Option C. Simeprevir inhibits the protease of hepatitis C: Simeprevir is a direct-acting antiviral agent that inhibits the protease enzyme of the hepatitis C virus. It is used in combination with other antiviral medications for the treatment of chronic hepatitis C infection.

Option D. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu: Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication that is commonly used for the treatment and prevention of influenza (flu) caused by influenza A and B viruses, including the H1N1 strain (commonly known as swine flu).

questions.text: Sandfly does not transmit:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: Option D: Sandfly does not transmit trench fever.

Trench fever is a bacterial infection caused by Bartonella quintana. It is typically transmitted by the human body louse (Pediculus humanus). Sandflies, on the other hand, are primarily known for transmitting other diseases, particularly those caused by protozoan parasites.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Kala azar (Visceral leishmaniasis): Sandflies, particularly species of the genus Phlebotomus in the Old World and Lutzomyia in the New World, are the primary vectors of Leishmania parasites, which cause kala azar or visceral leishmaniasis. 

Option B. Oriental sore (Cutaneous leishmaniasis): The disease is caused by various species of Leishmania parasites and is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected sandflies.

Option C. Oraya fever (Sandfly fever): Oraya fever, also known as sandfly fever. Sandflies, specifically species of the genus Phlebotomus and Sergentomyia, act as vectors for the transmission of these viruses to humans.

questions.text:
Assertion: In a patient admitted in hospital for community – acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta – lactams and azithromycin is given.

Reason: This combination covers Gram – positive organisms and anaerobes

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false
The assertion is false but reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Assertion is true, but the reason is false:

  • The assertion states that in a patient admitted to the hospital for community-acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta-lactams and azithromycin is given. This assertion is true, as this combination therapy is a commonly recommended approach for treating community-acquired pneumonia.
  • The reason provided is that this combination covers Gram-positive organisms and anaerobes. However, this reason is false. Beta-lactams, such as penicillin or cephalosporins, primarily target Gram-positive bacteria, while azithromycin has broader coverage against Gram-negative bacteria and atypical pathogens. It does not specifically target anaerobes. Therefore, the reason is incorrect and does not provide a valid explanation for the assertion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is incorrect because the reason provided is false.

Option B - Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is incorrect because the reason provided is false and does not explain the assertion.

Option D - Both assertion and reason are false: This option is incorrect because the assertion is true, but the reason is false.

questions.text: What is the clinical application of tafenoquine among the options provided?

choices.text: Treatment of malaria in children <2 years

questions.solution:
Correct Option A.

Tafenoquine is an antimalarial medication used for the radical cure (prevention of relapse) of Plasmodium vivax malaria. It is effective in eliminating the dormant liver stages (hypnozoites) of the parasite, which are responsible for causing relapses of the disease. Tafenoquine is administered as a single dose in combination with a blood schizonticide, typically chloroquine.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy: Tafenoquine is not recommended for prophylaxis of malaria in pregnancy due to limited safety data.

Option C. Treatment of severe falciparum malaria: Tafenoquine is not indicated for the treatment of severe falciparum malaria. It is primarily used for Plasmodium vivax malaria.

Option D. Treatment of malaria in children <2 years: Tafenoquine is not approved for use in children younger than 18 years of age.

questions.text: The bone marrow density along with the gestational age is plotted from two different studies. Which of the following is true for the relation between bone marrow density and gestational age?

choices.text: Strength of correlation is same in A and B
Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B
Strength of the variation is more in B than A
Variation in variables is more with A than B

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Strength of the correlation is more in A than in B:

  • Study A shows a stronger correlation between bone marrow density and gestational age compared to Study B.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Strength of the correlation is the same in A and B: This contradicts Option B, which highlights a difference in correlation strength between the studies.

Option C - Strength of the variation is more in B than A: This addresses variability, not correlation strength, making it an incorrect choice.

Option D - Variation in variables is more with A than B: This also refers to variability, not correlation strength, thus it's incorrect.

questions.text: During a study, one group (group A) was administered a placebo, while another group (group B) was given a new medication. In group A, 36 out of 120 patients died, whereas in group B, 26 out of 130 patients died. How many patients need to be treated in order to prevent one death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 10:

  • To calculate the number needed to treat (NNT) to avert 1 death, we use the formula NNT = 1 / (Risk Difference). In this case, the Risk Difference is 0.1, calculated by subtracting the mortality rate in the treated group (26/130) from that in the control group (36/120).

  • So, NNT = 1 / 0.1 = 10. Therefore, 10 patients need to be treated to avert 1 death.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 100:  This option is incorrect because it doesn't align with the calculated NNT, which is 10.

Option C -250: This option is incorrect because it would result in a larger number of patients needing to be treated to avert 1 death.

Option D -160: This option is incorrect because it doesn't align with the calculated NNT, which is 10.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used for calculation of anatomical dead space ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Single breath nitrogen test: 

  • The single breath nitrogen test is a method used to estimate anatomical dead space. It involves inhaling pure oxygen and then exhaling slowly and steadily.
  • The alveolar oxygen is mixed with the nitrogen whereas the air in the anatomical dead space is free of nitrogen containing only oxygen thus measuring the anatomical dead space

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Multiple breath nitrogen test: It is used for measuring the residual volume.

Option B - Bohr’s method: it is used for measuring the physiological dead space.

Option C - Spirometry: Spirometry is a commonly used test to assess lung function and measure various parameters such as forced vital capacity (FVC), forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR).

questions.text: Regarding ASHA, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A-Malaria slide preparation.

ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) is a community health worker under the National Rural Health Mission in India. ASHAs play a vital role in providing primary healthcare services and promoting health awareness in their communities. They are trained to perform various tasks to improve the health of individuals and communities.

ASHAs are not responsible for malaria slide preparation. Malaria slide preparation is typically performed by trained laboratory technicians or healthcare professionals.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Ensure immunization as per schedule:This option is true. One of the key roles of ASHAs is to promote immunization and ensure that individuals receive vaccines as per the recommended schedule.

Option C: Accompany pregnant women to the hospital:This option is true. ASHAs accompany pregnant women to hospitals or healthcare facilities for antenatal check-ups, delivery, and postnatal care.

Option D: Spread awareness about contraception: This option is true. ASHAs actively engage in spreading awareness about contraception methods, family planning, and reproductive health.

questions.text: On which receptor does Hepcidin act to hinder the absorption of iron?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ferroportin:

  • Ferroportin is a transmembrane protein facilitating iron release from cells like enterocytes and macrophages.
  • Hepcidin, produced by the liver, regulates iron levels by binding to ferroportin, triggering its internalization and degradation, thereby reducing iron release into the bloodstream. This inhibition decreases iron absorption from the intestines and iron release from macrophages, resulting in decreased iron levels in circulation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DMT-1: DMT-1 (divalent metal transporter 1) is a transmembrane protein responsible for transporting iron into cells.

Option C - Hephaestin: Hephaestin is an enzyme involved in iron metabolism, particularly in the release of iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream.

Option D - Transferrin: Transferrin is a protein that binds to iron in the bloodstream and transports it to cells.

questions.text: Doll and hills is an example of?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prospective Cohort:

  • Prospective cohort studies follow individuals over time to investigate the relationship between exposures and outcomes. Examples include studies on smoking and lung cancer, heart health, and the effects of oral contraceptives.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect

questions.text: In which of the following outbreaks is mass vaccination considered to be the most effective?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Polio:

  • Mass vaccination is most effective for diseases preventable through vaccination and with high vaccine coverage achievable.
  • Polio is highly infectious, especially in children, but can be prevented through vaccination.
  • Mass vaccination campaigns for polio aim for high vaccine coverage to interrupt transmission and protect susceptible individuals.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cholera: Controlled through other measures like water and sanitation improvements.

Option B - Typhoid: Usually targeted at high-risk groups, not mass campaigns.

Option D - Whooping cough: prevented by vaccination but not typically through mass campaigns.

questions.text: Which of the options below does not characterize melancholia?

choices.text: Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sleep-onset insomnia:

  • Sleep-onset insomnia: This symptom is not typically associated with melancholia. Instead, individuals with melancholia may experience early morning awakening.
  • Melancholia, also known as melancholic depression, is a subtype of major depressive disorder.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Severe anhedonia: Anhedonia refers to the inability to experience pleasure or enjoy activities that were previously enjoyable. In melancholia, this symptom is typically severe.

Option B - Weight loss: Melancholia often leads to significant weight loss due to reduced appetite and decreased interest in eating.

Option D - Profound feelings of guilt over trivial events: Melancholia is often accompanied by excessive guilt and self-blame, even for minor or trivial events.

questions.text: Please observe the provided image and choose the linear regression equation that matches the displayed graph.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- which is y = 11 + 2x. :

In the given graph, the relationship between the x and y variables appears to be a linear relationship, with a positive slope. The equation y = 11 + 2x represents this relationship accurately. It suggests that for every unit increase in x, y increases by 2 units, and the line intersects the y-axis at 11.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

Option A. y = 10 – x: This equation represents a line with a negative slope, which is not consistent with the positive slope observed in the graph.

Option B. x = 10 + y: This equation represents a line with a slope of 1, where x increases by 1 unit for every unit increase in y. This is not consistent with the slope observed in the graph.

Option D. x = 11 + 2y: This equation represents a line with a slope of 1/2, where x increases by 1 unit for every 2 unit increase in y. This is not consistent with the slope observed in the graph.

questions.text: A study was done to assess the risk factors for breast cancer in 100 females from urban cities. A statistical group and analysis are shown below. The values indicate the odds ratio and the 95% confidence interval. How many risk factors may be ascertained from the statistical analysis of the research?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 5:

  • Based on the statistical analysis, 5 risk factors can be ascertained from the research. 
  • Odds ratio -
    • OR >1 Association present
    • OR = 1 No association
    • OR < Inverse/negative association

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are not the correct answer, as there is the presence of 5 risk factors; they show an odd ratio of more than 1.

questions.text: What is a true statement regarding depersonalization disorder?

choices.text: More common after life threatening trauma
Seen in seizure and migraine patients
Mean age at onset is 25 years

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - More common after life threatening trauma:

  • Depersonalization disorder is a dissociative disorder characterized by persistent or recurrent episodes of depersonalization, where individuals feel detached from themselves and their experiences. It is often associated with significant distress and impairment in daily functioning. While the exact cause of depersonalization disorder is unclear, it is commonly observed that it can be triggered or exacerbated by traumatic experiences, including life-threatening events.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Seen in seizure and migraine patients: Depersonalization disorder is not specifically associated with seizure or migraine patients. It is a distinct psychiatric condition unrelated to these neurological disorders.

Options C - More common in females: Depersonalization disorder does not show a significant gender bias. It can affect both males and females equally.

Options D - Mean age at onset is 25 years: The age of onset for depersonalization disorder can vary, and there is no specific mean age at onset. It can occur at any age, but it often manifests during adolescence or early adulthood.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding a nurse's needle stick injury during blood sampling from an HIV-positive patient is false?

choices.text: Washing hands with soap and water
Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Administration of tenofovir monotherapy:

  • This option is incorrect because administering tenofovir monotherapy alone is not the recommended course of action following a needle stick injury. Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is the standard approach, which involves a combination of antiretroviral medications to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Washing hands with soap and water: Washing hands with soap and water helps remove any blood or bodily fluid that may be present on the skin.

Option C - Measure baseline viral markers of healthcare worker immediately: Measuring the baseline viral markers of the healthcare worker, including HIV antibody testing, allows for a baseline assessment of their infection status.

Option D - Measure viral markers after 6 weeks: Testing viral markers, including HIV antibody testing, after 6 weeks allows for the detection of any seroconversion (the development of detectable antibodies) that may have occurred as a result of the needle stick injury.

questions.text: What is the optimal approach to assess the injection practices of healthcare personnel?

choices.text: Direct observation with a structured checklist
In-depth interview with the healthcare provider

questions.solution:
Correct Option-A: Direct observation with a structured checklist

Direct observation with a structured checklist is considered the best method to survey the injection practices of health workers. This approach involves trained observers directly observing the injection procedures and practices of healthcare providers and using a structured checklist to document their findings.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Closed circuit camera surveillance: While closed circuit camera surveillance can provide visual recordings of injection practices, it may lack the ability to capture important details and nuances of the process.

Option C. In-depth interview with the patient: While patient perspectives and experiences are valuable, relying solely on in-depth interviews with patients may not provide a comprehensive understanding of injection practices.

Option D. In-depth interview with the healthcare provider: In-depth interviews may not capture the actual practices in a real-world setting and may be subject to recall bias or social desirability bias.

questions.text: What is the etiology of delirium tremens in a 48-year-old male who presents to the emergency room with symptoms of confusion and generalized body tremors, and has a known history of heavy alcohol use?

choices.text: Small does of regular consumption of alcohol

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Gradual withdrawal of alcohol:

  • Delirium tremens in an alcoholic is caused by the gradual withdrawal of alcohol. Abrupt cessation or significant reduction of alcohol intake leads to hyperexcitability of the brain, resulting in the manifestation of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute infection: Acute infection is not the cause of delirium tremens in an alcoholic. Delirium tremens occurs due to alcohol withdrawal.

Option B - Fatty liver: Fatty liver is not the direct cause of delirium tremens. It is a consequence of chronic alcohol abuse but does not directly lead to delirium tremens.

Option D - Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol: Small doses of regular alcohol consumption are not the cause of delirium tremens. It occurs with the withdrawal of alcohol rather than regular consumption.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a primary level of prevention for specific protection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hand washing:

  • Hand washing is not a primary prevention measure for specific protection. It's crucial for general hygiene but doesn't target preventing a specific disease.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meningitis prophylaxis: Provides preventive treatment to close contacts to stop meningitis spread.

Option C - Vaccination: Administering vaccines prevents targeted diseases.

Option D - Iron fortification: Adding iron to food prevents iron deficiency anaemia.

questions.text: The following image of a FAST scan in a trauma patient suggests:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Positive FAST:

  • A positive FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma) scan is indicated by the presence of abnormal findings suggesting internal bleeding or organ injury in the abdomen or chest.
  • This means that the scan has detected abnormalities, such as the presence of free fluid or blood in the abdomen or chest, indicating potential internal injuries.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Negative FAST: A negative FAST scan would indicate the absence of any abnormal findings, suggesting no significant internal bleeding or organ injury.

Option C: Equivocal FAST: An equivocal FAST scan implies that the findings are inconclusive or uncertain and require further evaluation or additional imaging.

Option D: Pneumoperitoneum:

  • Pneumoperitoneum refers to the presence of air or gas in the abdominal cavity, typically indicating a perforation in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • While a FAST scan can detect fluid or blood, it is not typically used to diagnose pneumoperitoneum.
  • Other imaging modalities, such as X-rays or CT scans, are more suitable for diagnosing pneumoperitoneum.

questions.text: The current recommended treatment for paucibacillary leprosy is the Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) which includes the combination of rifampicin, dapsone, and clofazimine. The latest recommended regimen is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 2 drug therapy for 6 months:

  • The treatment of paucibacillary leprosy, which is a milder form of the disease, involves-
    • Rifampin 600mg once a month supervised
    • Dapsone 100 mg daily self-administered.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of an 8-year-old child who has been experiencing a cough for the past 7 months, hemoptysis for 1 month, and fever for 4 days, as shown in the provided X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B.

Based on the given history and X-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis is consolidation. Consolidation refers to the solidification of lung tissue, usually due to the accumulation of inflammatory exudate or cellular infiltrates within the air spaces. It typically presents with symptoms such as cough, fever, and in some cases, hemoptysis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Lung abscess: Lung abscess is characterized by a localized collection of pus within the lung parenchyma. It may present with similar symptoms as consolidation, but on an X-ray, it typically appears as a cavity or a well-defined round lesion with an air-fluid level.

Option C. Hydatid cyst: Hydatid cyst is a parasitic infection caused by the larval stage of Echinococcus granulosus. It typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging, often containing daughter cysts. The X-ray provided does not show the characteristic features of a hydatid cyst.

Option D. Thoracic duct malformation: Thoracic duct malformation refers to abnormalities in the structure or function of the thoracic duct, which is responsible for draining lymphatic fluid from the thoracic region. It does not appear to be relevant to the given history and X-ray findings.

questions.text: What does the numerator of perinatal mortality rate consist of?

choices.text: Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Early neonatal death of fetus > 1000 g:

  • Perinatal mortality rate includes stillbirths and early neonatal deaths per 1,000 total births. It's calculated as (Total Stillbirths + Early Neonatal Deaths of fetus > 1000 g) / Total Births × 1,000.
  • It's crucial for assessing newborn and maternal health.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Post-neonatal period death: Not part of perinatal mortality.

Option C - Stillbirth of fetus < 500 g: Not included in perinatal mortality.

Option D - Abortion after 16 weeks: Not part of perinatal mortality.

questions.text: At what point can a patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock be released from the hospital?

choices.text: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - After the return of appetite:

  • The return of appetite is an important indicator of improvement in a patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock. When a patient regains their appetite, it suggests that their body is recovering and they are able to tolerate oral intake. It indicates that the patient's condition has stabilized, and they can start resuming normal food consumption, which is a positive sign of recovery.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol:

  • While controlling fever is important, it alone does not indicate the patient's overall improvement or readiness for discharge.

Option C - Urine output more than 200ml:

  • While adequate urine output is important to monitor the patient's hydration status and kidney function, it is not the sole criterion for determining the discharge of a patient with dengue hemorrhagic shock. 

Option D - After 24 hours from recovery of shock:

  • The recovery from shock is just one aspect to consider when deciding to discharge a patient. Other factors, such as stability of vital signs, absence of bleeding, and overall clinical improvement, should also be assessed before discharging the patient.
