questions.text: What is the probable pathogen responsible for the lesions seen on the palm of a 5-year-old child with a 3-day history of fever and changes in consciousness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Picornavirus:

  • The patient’s presentation with fever and lesions on the palm is suggestive of hand foot mouth disease.
  • Picornaviruses are a family of RNA viruses that include various viruses such as Enterovirus and Coxsackievirus.
  • These viruses can cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD).
  • HFMD typically presents with fever, sore throat, and characteristic skin lesions on the palms, soles of the feet, and mouth.

Incorrect Options:

Palm lesions are not seen in options A, B, and C.

questions.text: Duration of action of Proparacaine:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 20 min:

  • The duration of action of Proparacaine is relatively short, around 20 minutes. This means that its effects will typically last for approximately 20 minutes after application. It provides temporary and localized anesthesia to the eye, allowing for the performance of necessary procedures without causing significant discomfort to the patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2 min: This option suggests an extremely short duration of action, which is not consistent with the typical effects of Proparacaine.

Option B - 5 min: This option suggests a slightly longer duration of action compared to option A, but it is still shorter than the correct answer

Option C - 40 min: This option suggests a significantly longer duration of action, which is not consistent with the properties of Proparacaine.

questions.text: Which nerve injury is responsible for the development of postoperative aspiration in a patient who underwent surgery at the lateral part of the skull without any change in voice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glossopharyngeal nerve:

Glossopharyngeal nerve injury. Damage to the glossopharyngeal nerve can disrupt the normal sensory feedback involved in the swallowing reflex. This can result in impaired swallowing and aspiration, particularly in the postoperative period when swallowing may be compromised.
 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - High vagal injury: The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) plays a role in several functions, including swallowing and voice production. However, a "high vagal injury" typically refers to damage to the vagus nerve at or above the level of the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) and recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) branches. High vagal injuries are more likely to affect voice production rather than cause isolated aspiration without voice change.

Option B - Recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve) innervates the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, which are crucial for voice production. Damage can lead to vocal cord paralysis and voice changes, but it is not typically associated with isolated aspiration without voice change.

Option C - Superior laryngeal nerve: The superior laryngeal nerve (also a branch of the vagus nerve) has two branches: the internal branch and the external branch. Damagecan affect the sensory innervation of the larynx above the vocal cords but is less likely to cause aspiration without voice change. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) plays a role in swallowing and sensory functions in the throat, including the sensation of the oropharynx. Damage can lead to impaired swallowing and potential aspiration.

questions.text: Identify the device shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Automated external defibrillator:

  • An automated external defibrillator (AED) is a portable electronic device used to diagnose and treat life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias, specifically ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia, through the application of an electric shock to the heart. It is designed to be user-friendly and can be used by individuals with minimal medical training.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Automated External Desynchronizer: This is not a recognized device in the context of medical emergency management. It appears to be an incorrect or fictional term.

Option C - Automated Electronic Defibrillator: This is not a recognized term for a specific medical device. It may be a combination of terms, but it does not accurately represent the device shown in the image.

Option D - Automated External Decompressor: This is not a recognized term for a medical device. It does not relate to the purpose or function of the device shown in the image.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of the external carotid artery (ECA) supplying the nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A - Anterior ethmoidal artery:

  • The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, which is a branch of the internal carotid artery. . .

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sphenopalatine artery:

  • The sphenopalatine artery is a branch of the maxillary artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery.

Option C - Greater palatine artery:

  • The greater palatine artery is a branch of the maxillary artery.

Option D - Superior labial artery:

  • The superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery, which is a branch of the external carotid artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Well controlled asthma:

  • Well controlled asthma is not considered a significant risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications. When asthma is well controlled, the risk of complications is generally lower compared to uncontrolled or severe asthma.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - BMI >30:

  • Obesity, indicated by a BMI greater than 30, is a known risk factor for postoperative pulmonary complications. It can impair lung function and increase the risk of respiratory complications after surgery.

Option C - Upper abdominal surgery:

  • Upper abdominal surgeries, such as surgeries involving the chest, abdomen, or diaphragm, can impact respiratory function due to the proximity to the respiratory muscles and potential effects on lung expansion. This increases the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications.

Option D - Age >70 years:

  • Advanced age is associated with decreased respiratory reserve and decreased lung function, making older individuals more susceptible to postoperative pulmonary complications.

questions.text: Mark the false statement :

choices.text: Ansa cervicalis lies on the posterior wall of carotid sheath
Carotid sheath is formed by investing layer of deep cervical fascia
Sympathetic chain lies between internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein
Common carotid artery divides at the level of lower border of thyroid cartilage

questions.solution:
The statement that is false is:

3. Sympathetic chain lies between internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein.

Explanation of the options:

  1. Ansa cervicalis lies on the posterior wall of the carotid sheath: This statement is generally correct. The ansa cervicalis is a loop of nerves from the cervical plexus, and it runs on the posterior wall of the carotid sheath.

  2. Carotid sheath is formed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia: This statement is correct. The carotid sheath is a tubular structure that contains the common carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve. It is formed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

  3. Sympathetic chain lies between internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein: This statement is false. The sympathetic chain (sympathetic trunk) typically runs alongside and posterior to the carotid sheath structures, including the internal carotid artery and internal jugular vein. It is located posterior to these structures, not between them.

  4. Common carotid artery divides at the level of the lower border of the thyroid cartilage: This statement is generally correct. The common carotid artery bifurcates into the internal carotid artery and the external carotid artery at the level of the upper border of the thyroid cartilage in the neck.

So, the false statement is option 3, as the sympathetic chain is situated posterior to the structures within the carotid sheath, rather than between them.

questions.text: A 28 years female patient presented with history of bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. She can hear better in noisy environment. Examination showed intact eardrums bilaterally and Rinne test is negative bilaterally. Pure tone audiometry given below. What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Stapedial otosclerosis:

Stapedial otosclerosis is a condition characterized by the abnormal growth and fixation of the stapes bone in the middle ear. It results in conductive hearing loss, tinnitus, and negative Rinne test results. The audiogram provided shows a typical pattern of conductive hearing loss, with the air conduction thresholds (AC) higher than the bone conduction thresholds (BC). Therefore, option C is the most probable diagnosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meniere's disease: Meniere's disease is characterized by recurring episodes of vertigo, hearing loss, tinnitus, and a feeling of fullness in the affected ear. While hearing loss and tinnitus are present in both Meniere's disease and stapedial otosclerosis, Meniere's disease is typically associated with fluctuating hearing loss and positive Rinne test results (air conduction better than bone conduction), whereas stapedial otosclerosis is associated with conductive hearing loss and negative Rinne test results (bone conduction better than air conduction).

Option B - Endolymphatic fistula: An endolymphatic fistula is an abnormal connection between the inner ear's fluid-filled spaces and the middle ear. It can cause symptoms such as hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo. However, the audiogram pattern and negative Rinne test seen in the provided case are not consistent with an endolymphatic fistula.

Option D - Vestibular schwannoma: Vestibular schwannoma, also known as acoustic neuroma, is a benign tumor that develops on the vestibular nerve. It can cause symptoms such as hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance. However, the negative Rinne test and the specific audiogram pattern shown in the case are more consistent with stapedial otosclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with respiratory alkalosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Assisted control mode ventilation:

  • Respiratory alkalosis is a condition characterized by a decrease in arterial carbon dioxide levels, leading to an increase in blood pH.
  • It is caused by hyperventilation or excessive elimination of CO2 from the body.
  • In assisted control mode ventilation, the ventilator delivers breaths at a preset rate and tidal volume, and the patient can initiate additional breaths on their own.
  • This mode of ventilation can lead to increased minute ventilation and respiratory alkalosis due to excessive elimination of CO2.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Controlled mandatory ventilation (CMV):

  • In this mode, the ventilator delivers breaths at a preset rate and tidal volume, and the patient has no control over initiating breaths.
  • It does not typically cause respiratory alkalosis as the ventilator controls the entire breathing pattern.

Option C - Pressure-controlled ventilation:

  • This mode of ventilation delivers breaths with a set inspiratory pressure and allows the patient to determine the respiratory rate and tidal volume.
  • While it can affect blood gas parameters, it does not specifically lead to respiratory alkalosis.

Option D - SIMV (Synchronized Intermittent Mandatory Ventilation):

  • SIMV is a mode of ventilation that combines mandatory breaths delivered by the ventilator with the patient's spontaneous breaths.
  • It allows the patient to breathe spontaneously between the mandatory breaths.
  • SIMV does not directly cause respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the diagnosis of accelerated phase of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)?

choices.text: Leukocytosis more than 1000 ×106 not responding to treatment
Blast concentration in PBS should be greater than 15%
Increased spleen size not responsive to therapy
No response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Leukocytosis more than 1000 × 10^6 not responding to treatment:

  • Leukocytosis more than 1000 × 10^6 is actually a characteristic feature of the accelerated phase of CML. However, it's important to note that the response to treatment can vary, and the lack of response to treatment is not specific to the diagnosis of the accelerated phase of CML.

Incorrect options:

Option B - Blast concentration in PBS should be greater than 15%

  • This statement is true. Blast concentration in PBS should be greater than 15% is one of the diagnostic criteria for accelerated phase of CML.

Option C - Increased spleen size not responsive to therapy.

  • This statement is true. In the accelerated phase of CML, the spleen typically becomes enlarged (splenomegaly), and this enlargement may not respond adequately to therapy.

Option D - No response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

  • This statement is true. In the accelerated phase of CML, there may be a reduced response or lack of response to tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) therapy, which is the standard treatment for CML.

questions.text: In a post-operative patient, after 2 hours of receiving FFP, sudden onset dyspnea, hypoxemia, tachypnea, hypotension, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest X-ray occur. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - TRALI (Transfusion-related acute lung injury):

  • TRALI is a severe adverse reaction that can occur within a few hours of FFP transfusion. It is characterized by the sudden onset of respiratory distress, pulmonary edema, and hypotension.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B - TACO (Transfusion-associated circulatory overload) - Presents with circulatory overload and pulmonary edema, but not tachypnea.

Option C - Pulmonary edema - General term for fluid accumulation in the lungs, but does not explain the specific findings mentioned.

Option D - ARDS (Acute respiratory distress syndrome) - Presents with severe respiratory distress, but the X-ray appearance is different (diffuse alveolar damage).

Option E - Sepsis - Infection-related, but does not explain the specific findings mentioned.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is false?   	Polygenic inheritance 	Lamotrigine helps in controlling myoclonic jerks 	Benzodiazepines alone can control myoclonic jerks 	Valproate should be avoided
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - (1, 2, and 3 are correct):

  • This option correctly states that statements 1, 2, and 3 are true, while statement 4 is incorrect.
  1. Polygenic inheritance: This statement is true. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) is believed to have a polygenic inheritance pattern.
  2. Lamotrigine helps in controlling myoclonic jerks: This statement is true. Lamotrigine is effective in controlling myoclonic jerks, which are a characteristic symptom of the condition.
  3. Benzodiazepines alone can control myoclonic jerks: This statement is also true. Benzodiazepines, such as clonazepam, are frequently used as a first-line treatment for myoclonic jerks in JME.

 

Incorrect statement

  • Valproate should be avoided: This statement is incorrect. Valproate is used in the treatment of JMS and should be taken lifelong.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions will the pneumococcal vaccine PPV-23 provide the greatest advantage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sickle cell anemia:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine PPV-23, is recommended to prevent pneumococcal infections in individuals with sickle cell anemia.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Recurrent rhinitis and sinusitis: While recurrent rhinitis and sinusitis may be troublesome conditions, they are not specifically indications for the pneumococcal vaccine PPV-23.

Option B - Cystic fibrosis: Specific guidelines and recommendations for vaccination in individuals with cystic fibrosis, and the choice of pneumococcal vaccine (PPV-13 or PPV-23) may depend on various factors, including age and previous vaccination history.

Option D - Child <2 years: The PPV-23 vaccine is typically given to individuals aged 2 years and older who are at increased risk of invasive pneumococcal disease.

questions.text: A 48 years old man, hospitalized for 17 days and on IV antibiotics followed by oral course of drugs for acute febrile illness with neutropenia. He had a history of dysuria while admitted and now complaints of loose stools and abdominal pain. Which antibiotic usage has the highest risk for developing pseudomembranous colitis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Aminopenicillin:

  • Pseudomembranous colitis, also known as Clostridium difficile-associated colitis, is a severe inflammatory condition of the colon that can occur as a result of antibiotic usage. Certain antibiotics are known to disrupt the normal gut flora and create an environment favourable for the overgrowth of Clostridium difficile bacteria, leading to the development of pseudomembranous colitis.
  • Among the options provided, aminopenicillin antibiotics have the highest risk for causing pseudomembranous colitis. Aminopenicillins, such as ampicillin and amoxicillin, are broad-spectrum antibiotics commonly used to treat various bacterial infections. However, they can also disrupt the balance of the gut microbiota and increase the risk of Clostridium difficile infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Carbapenems: Carbapenems are a class of broad-spectrum antibiotics with a lower risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis compared to aminopenicillins. Although they can still disrupt the gut microbiota, their use is not typically associated with a significantly high risk of Clostridium difficile infection.

Option C - Macrolides: Macrolide antibiotics, such as erythromycin and azithromycin, are known to have a lower risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis compared to aminopenicillins. While they can still alter the gut microbiota, they are not considered as high-risk antibiotics for Clostridium difficile infection.

Option D - Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone antibiotics, including ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin, have a moderate risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis. While their use can disrupt the gut microbiota and increase the risk of Clostridium difficile infection, the risk is lower compared to aminopenicillins.

questions.text: Which of the following exists in yeast form at 37ºC and hyphal form at 25ºC?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Histoplasma Capsulatum:

  • Dimorphic fungi exist as molds in the environment at 25°C and as yeasts in human tissues at 37°C.
  • Several medically important fungi are thermally dimorphic, such as:
    • Histoplasma capsulatum
    • Blastomyces dermatitidis
    • Coccidioides immitis
    • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
    • Penicillium marneffei
    • Sporothrix schenckii.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. They are not dimorphic fungus.

questions.text:
Assertion: Malathion is used as ultra – low volume (ULV) during epidemics

Reason: Ultra low volume fogger has residual effects

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false
The assertion is false but reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct option C - Assertion is true, but the reason is false:

  • The assertion states that Malathion is used as an ultra-low volume (ULV) during epidemics, which is true, and the reason that ultra-low volume defoggers have residual effects is wrong. Malathion is the least toxic organophosphorus compound commonly used as an insecticide during disease outbreaks, particularly for dengue-hemorrhagic fever and mosquito-borne encephalitis epidemics. ULV refers to the method of applying a small volume of insecticide as fine droplets, which allows for effective coverage and control of mosquitoes or other vector populations.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text:
Assertion: WHO recommends Typhoid vaccine for disaster management in endemic areas

Reason: Vaccination is a cost – effective measure of disaster control

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Both assertion and reason are false:

  • Assertion: The statement that WHO recommends Typhoid vaccine for disaster management in endemic areas is false. WHO does not specifically recommend Typhoid vaccine as a measure of disaster management in endemic areas. While vaccination can be an important public health intervention, the specific recommendation of Typhoid vaccine for disaster management in endemic areas is not supported.
  • Reason: The reason provided, stating that vaccination is a cost-effective measure of disaster control, is also false. While vaccination can be cost-effective in certain situations, its effectiveness and cost-effectiveness depend on various factors such as the specific disease, population, vaccine availability, and infrastructure. The reason does not specifically support the assertion mentioned in the question.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: All of the following are signs of reversible cell injury, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dense mitochondrial deposit:

  • Mitochondrial changes, such as swelling and dysfunction, are associated with irreversible cell injury.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are associated with reversible cell injury.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statements regarding risk factors for postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Nulliparity

Explanation:

This statement is false. Nulliparity refers to a woman who has never given birth. While nulliparity itself is not a risk factor for PPH, it is important to note that first-time mothers (primiparous women) generally have a slightly higher risk of PPH compared to women who have had previous pregnancies.

 

Incorrect Option:

(Option A) Previous history of PPH: This statement is true. A previous history of PPH is considered a risk factor for experiencing PPH in subsequent pregnancies. Women who have had PPH before are more likely to have it again.

(Option B) Obese patient: This statement is true. Obesity is associated with an increased risk of PPH. The excess weight can contribute to uterine atony (ineffective uterine contractions) and difficulty in controlling bleeding after childbirth.

(Option D) Halogenated anesthetics: This statement is false. Halogenated anesthetics, such as halothane and isoflurane, have been associated with an increased risk of PPH. These anesthetics can relax the smooth muscle of the uterus, leading to uterine atony and increased bleeding after childbirth.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of itching during baths. His hemoglobin was 20%, his platelet count was 89000/mL, and his WBC count was 30,000/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Polycythemia Vera:

  • The clinical presentation of a 40-year-old male with complaints of itching during baths and laboratory findings of increased hemoglobin, decreased platelet count, and increased white blood cell count is suggestive of polycythemia vera.
  • Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells.
  • It is usually associated with an increase in hemoglobin and hematocrit.
  • Patients with polycythemia vera may experience symptoms such as pruritus (itching), especially after a warm bath or shower, due to increased histamine release caused by increased basophils in the blood.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Primary myelofibrosis:

  • Primary myelofibrosis, also known as idiopathic myelofibrosis, is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by bone marrow fibrosis, extramedullary hematopoiesis, and cytopenias.
  • It typically presents with anemia, splenomegaly, and other constitutional symptoms.

Option B - Chronic myeloid leukemia:

  • Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22.
  • CML typically presents with an increased white blood cell count, especially neutrophils, and splenomegaly.

Option D - Essential thrombocytosis:

  • Essential thrombocytosis, also known as primary thrombocythemia, is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of platelets.
  • It typically presents with an increased platelet count but does not usually cause significant changes in hemoglobin or white blood cell count.

questions.text:
Arrange the following clotting factors in the sequence that they follow in the coagulation cascade:


	13
	12
	10
	5
	9
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 2, 5, 3, 4, 1:

  • The coagulation cascade involves a series of sequential activation and interactions of various clotting factors, leading to the formation of a stable fibrin clot.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding a primigravida at 37 weeks gestation who has been diagnosed with a transverse lie?

choices.text: Transverse lie is associated with placenta previa
Repeat ultrasound to confirm the lie
Do cesarean section at once of labour
During cesarean section, deliver by breech

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A. Transverse lie is associated with placenta previa ( False ):

Transverse lie refers to a fetal position where the baby is lying sideways across the uterus, which can be diagnosed through ultrasound. It is not directly associated with placenta previa, which is a condition where the placenta partially or completely covers the cervix.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Repeat ultrasound to confirm the lie - This is important to accurately confirm the fetal position and plan the delivery method.

Option C. Admit at 36th week - This might be considered in some cases to closely monitor the mother and baby, especially if there are concerns about the baby's position.

Option D. Do cesarean section at the onset of labor - If a transverse lie is confirmed, a cesarean section is typically performed to ensure the safety of both the mother and the baby during delivery.

questions.text: Non – pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Male infertility.

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are commonly used in various medical conditions. These medications work by suppressing the release of gonadotropins, which are hormones that stimulate the production of sex hormones in the body. In certain conditions, a non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used, meaning a continuous or sustained dose is administered.

 

Incorrect Options:

Here is an explanation of the options:

Option A. Endometriosis: GnRH agonists are used in the treatment of endometriosis to reduce the symptoms and growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus. The non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist helps suppress the production of estrogen and provides relief from pain and other symptoms associated with endometriosis.

Option C. Precocious puberty: Precocious puberty refers to the early onset of puberty before the age of 9 in girls and 10 in boys. GnRH agonists are used in the treatment of precocious puberty to delay further pubertal development. The continuous or non-pulsatile administration of GnRH agonist helps suppress the premature release of sex hormones and slows down the progression of puberty.

OptionD. Carcinoma prostate: GnRH agonists are commonly used in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer. These medications help suppress the production of testosterone, which can fuel the growth of prostate cancer cells. The non-pulsatile dose of GnRH agonist is used to maintain a continuous suppression of testosterone levels and inhibit the growth of prostate cancer.

questions.text: What is the correct order of performing fetal scans during pregnancy?   	Triple markers 	Nuchal translucency scan 	Growth scan 	Anomalous can
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C. 2, 1, 4, 3: This option is correct. The correct sequential arrangement starts with the nuchal translucency scan, followed by the triple markers, then the anomalous scan, and finally the growth scan. This order is consistent with the recommended timing of these scans during pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. 1, 2, 3, 4: This option is incorrect. The sequential arrangement given in this option starts with the triple markers, followed by the nuchal translucency scan, growth scan, and finally the anomalous scan. However, the correct sequence should begin with the nuchal translucency scan, not the triple markers.

Option B. 3, 4, 1, 2: This option is incorrect. The sequential arrangement starts with the growth scan, followed by the anomalous scan, then the triple markers, and finally the nuchal translucency scan. The correct sequence should begin with the nuchal translucency scan, not the growth scan.

OptionD. 2, 1, 3,4 : This option is incorrect. The correct order is nuchal translucency scan, triple markers, anomalous scan, and growth scan.

questions.text:
Assertion: According to central dogma, information flows from DNA to RNA, which is then encoded into protein

Reason: In retrovirus, reversal of central dogma happens

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is correct not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false
The assertion is false but reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion:

  • Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is correct. The assertion correctly states that according to the central dogma, information flows from DNA to RNA, which is then encoded into protein. This is the general principle of information flow in most organisms. The reason, on the other hand, states that the reversal of the central dogma happens in retroviruses, which is true. However, this does not provide a correct explanation for the assertion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion: This option is incorrect. While both the assertion and reason are true, the reason provided does not correctly explain the assertion. However, the reason does not explain why the information flow from DNA to RNA is the correct explanation for the central dogma.

Option C - Assertion is true, but the reason is false: This option is incorrect. The assertion is true as per the central dogma, but the reason is also true as retroviruses do reverse the flow of information. Therefore, the reason is not false.

Option D - Both assertion and reason are false: This option is incorrect. Both the assertion and reason are true, as discussed above.

Option E - The assertion is false, but the reason is true: This option is incorrect. The assertion is true, as the central dogma indeed states that information flows from DNA to RNA to protein. The reason is also true, as retroviruses reverse this flow. Therefore, the assertion is not false.

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:
Option B. Cystoscopy: This option is correct.

The investigation of choice for vesicovaginal fistula (VVF) is a cystoscopy.

A vesicovaginal fistula is an abnormal connection between the bladder and the vagina, leading to the passage of urine from the bladder into the vagina. To diagnose and evaluate a vesicovaginal fistula, a cystoscopy is typically performed. During a cystoscopy, a thin, flexible tube with a camera (cystoscope) is inserted through the urethra and into the bladder. This allows the healthcare provider to directly visualize the interior of the bladder and identify any abnormal openings or connections.

Incorrect option:

Option A. IVP (Intravenous Pyelogram): This option is incorrect. An IVP is an imaging test that involves injecting a contrast dye into the bloodstream to visualize the urinary tract, including the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. While an IVP can help detect abnormalities in the urinary system, it is not the investigation of choice for diagnosing a vesicovaginal fistula.

Option C. 3 Swab Test: This option is Not correct. The "3 Swab Test" is a not diagnostic test for vesicovaginal fistula.

OptionD. X-ray: This option is incorrect. X-rays are not the investigation of choice for diagnosing a vesicovaginal fistula. While certain X-ray techniques, such as a retrograde urethrogram, may be used to evaluate urinary tract abnormalities, they are not specific or sensitive enough for diagnosing vesicovaginal fistulas.

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment choice for metropathia haemorrhagica?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. Cyclical progesterone: This option is correct. Cyclical progesterone therapy involves the administration of progesterone during specific phases of the menstrual cycle. It helps regulate the endometrium (lining of the uterus) and stabilize the uterine lining, reducing the excessive and irregular bleeding associated with metropathia haemorrhagica.

 

;Incorrect Option :

Option B. Hysterectomy: It is usually reserved for cases where conservative measures have failed or when there are other underlying reasons to warrant the removal of the uterus.

Option C. Uterine artery embolization: This option is incorrect. Uterine artery embolization (UAE) is a procedure used to treat uterine fibroids, which are benign growths in the uterus. It is not the primary treatment for metropathia haemorrhagica.

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This option is incorrect. D&C provides temporary relief by removing excess endometrial tissue but does not address the underlying hormonal imbalance.

questions.text: The treatment for the condition given below is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Extended Curettage with Autograft:

  • Giant cell tumor is a benign but locally aggressive tumor that commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones. The treatment of choice for giant cell tumor is surgical intervention. Extended curettage refers to the removal of the tumor by scraping and scooping out the affected bone. Autograft involves using bone graft material from the patient's own body to fill the resulting defect and promote bone healing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Extended Curettage with Allograft: Extended curettage with allograft is not the preferred treatment for giant cell tumors. Allograft refers to the use of bone graft material from a donor, which is not typically used in the treatment of giant cell tumors.

Option B - Bone Biopsy: Bone biopsy is a diagnostic procedure to obtain a sample of tissue for examination and confirmation of the diagnosis. While it may be performed as part of the diagnostic process, it is not the primary treatment for giant cell tumors.

Option C - Curettage: Curettage alone is not considered sufficient for the treatment of giant cell tumors. Extended curettage, as mentioned in option D, is a more comprehensive approach.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contribute to the development of head and neck malignancies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D - Vitamin A deficiency: While vitamin A deficiency can have various health implications and is associated with certain conditions, it is not directly linked to the development of head and neck malignancies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - EBV infection: EBV (Epstein-Barr virus) infection is associated with certain types of head and neck cancers, particularly nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option B - HPV infection: HPV (Human papillomavirus) infection is a well-established risk factor for oropharyngeal cancers, particularly those involving the tonsils and base of the tongue.
Option C - Betel nut: Betel nut, often chewed with or without tobacco, is a known risk factor for the development of oral cancers.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clear benefit of using high-pressure oxygen via nasal cannula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A. Decreases the need for intubation

  • High-flow oxygen therapy delivered via nasal cannula, also known as high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) therapy, has several benefits, but it does not necessarily decrease the need for intubation in all cases.
  • HFNC therapy can improve oxygenation, provide consistent and comfortable humidification, and reduce nasopharyngeal dead space, making it an effective therapy for patients with respiratory distress. However, the decision to intubate a patient is complex and depends on various factors, including the underlying condition, the severity of respiratory distress, and the patient's response to other therapies.
  • HFNC therapy may delay the need for intubation in some cases, but it does not eliminate the need entirely.

Incorrect Options

Option B. Reduces nasopharyngeal dead space: HFNC therapy delivers a high flow of oxygen that washes out the nasopharyngeal dead space, allowing for more efficient ventilation and oxygenation.

Option C. Heating and humidification: HFNC systems effectively heat and humidify the oxygen, preventing drying and irritation of the airways. This is particularly beneficial for patients requiring high-flow oxygen for extended periods.

Option D. PEEP (Positive End-Expiratory Pressure): HFNC can provide a degree of positive end-expiratory pressure, which helps keep the airways open, improve lung recruitment, and enhance oxygenation. This is especially useful in patients with atelectasis or other conditions where maintaining lung volume is important.

questions.text: What is the purpose of using glycopyrrolate as a pre-anesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
Option A: Glycopyrrolate

  • Glycopyrrolate is primarily used as a pre-anesthetic agent for reducing secretions in the respiratory tract and other body systems. It belongs to a class of drugs called anticholinergics, which work by inhibiting the effects of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter involved in various bodily functions.
  • In the context of anesthesia, excessive secretions in the respiratory tract can interfere with the airway management and ventilation during surgery.
  • By administering glycopyrrolate before anesthesia, the production of respiratory secretions is reduced, improving the visibility of the surgical field and facilitating proper respiratory function.

 

Option B: Sedative effect

  • Glycopyrrolate is not primarily used for its sedative effects. It does not have significant sedative properties and is mainly focused on reducing secretions.

Option C: Skeletal muscle relaxant

  • Glycopyrrolate is not used as a skeletal muscle relaxant. It primarily affects the cholinergic system and is not intended for muscle relaxation during anesthesia.

Option D: Anxiolytic

  • Glycopyrrolate is not used as an anxiolytic. Its main role is in reducing secretions rather than alleviating anxiety or promoting sedation

questions.text: You are working as an intern in ICU. Which of the following statements is incorrect about ABG report?

choices.text: Normal pH cannot rule out acid base disorder
Flush syringe with 0.5 ml heparin before taking the sample
If the modified Allen test is positive use an alternative site for sampling
Radial artery is preferred site for taking sample

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: If the modified Allen test is positive use an alternative site for sampling

A positive Allen test means that the patient has an adequate dual blood supply to the hand. A negative Allen test shows the patient may not have adequate dual blood supply, which would be a contraindication for catheterization, radial forearm flap harvest, or any procedure that may result in the occlusion of the vessel. Therefore this statement is incorrect.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Normal pH can't rule out an acid-base disorder: This statement is correct. Normal pH values in an ABG analysis do not rule out the presence of an acid-base disorder. Acid-base disorders involve disturbances in the pH, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2), and bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels. As the patients having a combination of metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis will have normal pH.

Option B. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood: This statement is correct. Heparin is typically added to the syringe before obtaining the arterial blood sample to prevent clotting of the blood in the syringe. Flushing the syringe will prevent clotting but leaving heparin behind will cause falsely low pH and bicarbonate.

Option D. Radial artery is the preferred site: This statement is correct. The radial artery is preferred as it usually has good collateral circulation with the ulnar artery.

questions.text:
Arrange the following components of the auditory pathway in the correct sequence from the outermost part to the innermost part:


	Lateral lemniscus
	Cochlear nuclei
	Medial geniculate body
	Inferior colliculus
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B - 2,1,4,3

This option is correct. The cochlear nuclei (2) are the first structures in the auditory pathway. The lateral lemniscus (1) follows the cochlear nuclei, then the inferior colliculus (4), and finally, the medial geniculate body (3). This sequence represents the correct flow from the periphery to the center of the auditory pathway.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D are incorrect as explained above.

questions.text: A young man with history of ear infection presents with a smooth erythematous swelling on mastoid process as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acute mastoiditis: Acute mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid process. It commonly occurs as a complication of untreated or inadequately treated ear infections. The smooth erythematous swelling seen in the image is consistent with the clinical presentation of acute mastoiditis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Furunculosis: Furunculosis refers to the formation of a boil or abscess in the skin, typically caused by bacterial infection of a hair follicle.

Option C - Fibrous dysplasia: Fibrous dysplasia is a condition characterized by the abnormal growth of fibrous tissue in place of normal bone. It typically presents with bone deformities and pain.

OptionD - Facial palsy: Facial palsy refers to the weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles. It can be caused by various factors, including infections, trauma, or nerve damage.

questions.text: A 22 year old college going student has a history of sexual exposure with commercial sex worker, he now presents with painful genital lesions and lymphadenopathy in the right inguinal region as given below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chancroid:

  • Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by the development of painful genital ulcers and regional lymphadenopathy. The painful ulcers are typically soft, irregular, and may have a necrotic base. Inguinal lymphadenopathy, particularly in one side (unilateral), is a common feature of chancroid.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Syphilis: Syphilis typically presents with painless genital ulcers known as chancres. Unlike chancroid, syphilis ulcers are usually firm, well-defined, and non-tender.

Option C - LGV (Lymphogranuloma venereum): LGV primarily affects the lymphatic system and can lead to swelling of lymph nodes in the groin region. However, the genital ulcers seen in chancroid are not a characteristic feature of LGV.

Option D - Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale): Donovanosis typically presents with painless, beefy red nodules or ulcers in the genital area. Unlike chancroid, donovanosis lesions are typically painless and do not cause significant lymphadenopathy.

questions.text:
Please arrange the following ocular medications according to their respective side effects.


	
		
			
			Column A
			
			
			Column B
			
		
		
			
			1. Amiodarone

			2. Digoxin

			3. Systemic steroids

			4. Hydroxychloroquine
			
			
			A. Retinopathy

			B. Cataract

			C. Yellow vision

			D. Optic neuropathy
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A:

  • It accurately matches the ocular drugs with their corresponding side effects.
    • Amiodarone (1) is associated with optic neuropathy (D).
    • Digoxin (2) is associated with yellow vision (C).
    • Systemic steroids (3) are associated with cataract formation (B).
    • Hydroxychloroquine (4) is associated with retinopathy (A).
